Jul 10 2005	Excellent!	We are currently staying at the Hotel Vitale and I totally agree with the reviews already posted. The hotel is located very well near Embarcadero and the Ferry building. If you don't like hotel breakfasts (I don't because I generally eat too much), the market hall is a few steps away and provides some excellent places. The design and the amenities are absolutely outstanding, the view even from the 2nd floor on Bay Bridge is amazing. F Streetcar is right at the back of the building for those who don't like to walk too much.

Jul 7 2005	The Hotel Vitale was Wonderful!	We stayed at the Hotel Vitale for a few days last week and we truly had a wonderful stay. These are first-class accomodations! The hotel was bright and beautiful and the staff was incredibly warm. Every staff member I passed asked me how I was doing, if I was enjoying the hotel, etc. A very personal touch....We would not hesitate to stay there again. Allow me to describe the hotel... It is located in a beautiful new section of town on Embarcadero and Mission, by Pier 1 and directly across the street from the historic Ferry Building (BTW - every Saturday there is a wonderful Farmers Market there where you can enjoy simply amazing fresh produce, flowers, herbs and food). The hotel is designed using the principles of simplicity, functionality and beauty. Everything is exactly as it should be... Very "Feng Shui". The beds are super comfortable (down comforters/pillows and silky sheets), the furniture is beautiful, functional, artfully crafted and simple. The rooms have wonderfully comfortable robes and slippers in the closet. The showers were awesome, as were the complimentary SugarBath products. Our room also had a plasma/lcd flat screen TV at the foot of our bed. The views from the high rooms on the bay side of the hotel are fabulous. We stayed on the 8th (top) floor and had a panoramic view of the Bay Bridge and the sunrise. Awesome to wake up to... Many (if not all) of the floors have terraces that you can go and sit out on to overlook the city. The hallways always had fresh flowers and candles for ambience. As far as the hotel bar/restaurant, we had a drink there and enjoyed it. The staff was quite courteous and were very attentive. I will also note that if you are looking for a "scene" the hotel bar could be it. After work the bar gets a good crowd, which is nice. By the way, one of the top 10 restaurants in the city ("Boulevard") is also directly across the street from the hotel. We had a great meal there.The hotel's proximity to everything is good. You have the SF buses 1 block away, light rail on the corner, limo service directly from the hotel and cable cars around the corner. If you like to walk, Fishermans Wharf (pier 39) is a 20 minute walk along the bay (a nice walk). A note about SF - This is a nice area to stay in - close proximity without the crowds (and everything that goes along with that) of staying directly on the wharf. The wharf is super-commercial. I prefer really being one with the city as opposed to being part of all of the tourist traps. Then I am free to enjoy some peace as well. My wife and I have stayed at many hotels, and we would absolutely not hesitate to recommed this one. We had a wonderful stay and were really bummed when vacation was over. I have been to SF dozens of times and this was one of my most enjoyable stays! We are already trying to figure out when we can go back...

Jun 29 2005	Hotel Vitale: A Fine Hotel	LOCATIONMy wife and I stayed for a week in this fine new hotel June 18-26. Its strongest advantage is its location on the corner of Mission and the Embarcadero, which gives easy access to central SF as well as the harbour. Close to the Bay Bridge, it sits opposite the Ferry Terminal, with wonderfully airy views across to the water if you get one of the appropriate rooms. The roof terraces offer some spectacular views of the surrounding area (see photos), but no shade is provided for the seating areas up there. The tramway departs alongside the hotel - downtown one way, Fisherman's Wharf the other - and it is a short stroll to the California-Van Ness cable car route. The Ferry Building itself is a great nearby resource for fresh foodstuffs and a variety of meals and snacks  but it does not open until 10am most mornings - as well as the ferry to Sausalito. The Embarcadero Centre is a useful nearby shopping mall.ROOMSThe modest exterior of the hotel has been the subject of architectural debate, but it is pleasant enough. The hotel lobby is somewhat cavernous and lacking in character, but the reception staff are young, bright and friendly. The bedrooms are modern and comfortable, with some stylish fittings. The artwork ranges, disappointingly, from the rather twee to the harshly modern. The flatscreen TV is a bonus, but we did not encounter the DVD player or IPod dock enjoyed by other reviewers (fortunately we brought our own). The bathrobes, slippers, and bathroom products are exceptional. Wardrobe space is rather limited, but the turndown service is well up to US preoccupations with this (for us) obscure ritual. Room service was impeccable and the housekeeping team a total delight.OTHER SERVICESThe spa service is terrific but rather limited. Contra another reviewer, the massage (from Sharon) was the best ever. The restaurant provides food of high quality, drawing upon the resources of the Farmers Market at the Ferry Terminal. We were deterred from evening dining by the noisy bar scene, but there are excellent restaurants a few yards away such as Boulevard, Shanghai 1930, and Slanted Door. It will obviously take some time for the embryonic herb garden to offer an effective buffer between the outside tables and the busy roadway.

Jun 18 2005 	Awesome! (but still a few kinks to work out...)	2nd time at the Hotel Vitale, this time only from a quick 1 night stay. Similar to my last stay, I had a Deluxe King City View room. As a nice surprise, I ended up on the Mission St. side which had a clear view of the Bay Bridge.Room furnishings were still in great shape. This room had a chaise type chair instead of the sofa in my prior room. Flat-screen TV is great as usual. Only drawback, they don't have a HDTV signal, so the image is "stretched" to fit the screen aspect ratio.Interesting item...on my original stay, housekeeping stopped by for turndown service. This time, none was offered. Not sure if this service was elimianted or not.Only kinks were as follows: wake-up call was 10 minutes late, shoes (after a complimentary overnight shoe shine) were not returned on time, and they missed delivering me the morrning paper. Not traumatic on the grand scheme of things, but definitely not common for a hotel of this caliber. They'll get better with age...just start-up issues in my estimation. If not for these minor glitches, I would have given 5 stars.

Jun 13 2005	An Outstanding Stay at The Hotel Vitale	My husband and I just returned from a romantic Saturday night stay at the Hotel Vitale, and we loved it. The service was great. The front desk attendant was very welcoming, helpful and prompt. He told us he would have the concierge call us in regards to restaurant suggestions after arriving to our room; the phone rang not more than five minutes after we got to our room. The concierge suggested restaurants and made reservations for us. We had a deluxe bay view king room which was beautiful, very clean and roomy. The decor was simple and contemporary, and the bed was very comfortable. The bathroom was roomy. The amenities were great. We enjoyed the clock radio/CD player (which was supplied with 4 CD's), the flat screen TV, the robes, slippers and wonderful toiletries. The aroma of lavender was wonderful as we walked down the hallways. The price we paid for the bay view was worth it; the view took my breath away as soon as I walked into the room. The location is great near the Embarcadero, Ferry Building, and bay. Some of the things that I did not prefer were the sliding bathroom door which leaves gaps when fully closed, the neighbors' voices at times through the adjoining door, some hallway noises (like doors closing), street noise that can be loud at times but didn't wake me up, and the full-length mirror mounted directly across from the toilet. Through another review, we learned that parking at the hotel was expensive, so we found street parking very close to the hotel. Although the room was somewhat pricey, we would definitely stay here again.

Jun 6 2005	Great but beware of the bathroom door	Just returned from a 4 night stay at the Hotel Vitale and can only rave about it. The ambiance is that of the W Hotel but at a much lower rate. The location is terrific - the Embarcadero is right across the street. service was excellent, room comfy and well appointed - the Fresh product line was the toiletries of choice.Now for a few caveats : the bathroom door is a sliding door and doesn't close all the way. So any sounds from within the bathroom can be heard by any other inhabitants in the room. We mentioned this to the front desk on checkout and were told that guests have been complaining about this issue since day one. Also, the spa, though lovely looking does not have competant massage therapists. They go through the motions, but don't really do anything. When asked to exert more pressure, one of them actually did the exact opposite. Lastly, beware the parking charge - it's $42/day. Our package included free valet parking, but we were inadvertently charged for parking (which was easily rectified by the front desk).These items not withstanding, I'd return to Hotel Vitale any time.

Jun 1 2005	New SF hotel	We returned from our 2 night stay at the Hotel Vital which opened recently. Location: It is located close to the freeway so it easy to find but so close that you hear traffic noise. It is right across the street from the newly remodeled Ferry building, which includes restaurants and shops, and down the street from Pier 39. Service: Upon making reservations we had to switch days and they were not especially friendly over the phone but not rude either. I suppose 'efficient' would be appropriate. The rooms are significantly more expensive during the week than the weekend which is the opposite of most places we visit. Our check-in was very pleasant and we did arrive four hours before check-in! We were greeted and to our surprise promptly given an available room. Hotel: The hotel has a modern, zen-like feel. The hallways are very dimly lit which may not be plus for many people. The artwork and lavendar pieces in the hallway are a nice touch. Our room was average sized with a great bed and nice linens. Flatscreen t.v., c.d. player with four c.d.s, bathroom amenties from the Fresh co. Our view was of a building wall but if you are able to get a view of the water, it would be amazing. My husband hated the bathroom door as it is more visually appealing than suited for privacy. Restaurant/Bar: We did not eat at the restaurant, although the menu looked great and it was crowded. The bar was nice and had a similar feel as the hotel with great service even though it was a busy night. Gym: We had the room to ourselves with a couple cardio machines,t.v.s, and free weights. Small room with no windows.Overall, we had a nice experience but were able to get an introductory rate. We would most likely look elsewhere for the current price.

May 23 2005	was blown away by Hotel Vitale	With all the great hotels in San Francisco it is hard to believe that there was room for one more. My friend had recommended the Hotel Vitale which just opened right across from the Ferry Building. We had views of the water and Bay Bridge from our hotel. Without a doubt the best views in San Francisco (and yes I have stayed at Mandarin and Park Hyatt).In addition to the great location and views the bed was without a doubt the most comfortable bed I have ever slept in. Also, the room had cool amenities like electric shades, Bose i-pod deck, DVD and flat screen TVs.It is one of the Joie De Vivre (spelling?) properties so the price was nice $199. the restaurant was yummy and the hotel is small enough that after 3 days we had a chance to get to know the staff.Anyway I loved the hotel and am the first one to right a nasty review so i thought I would take the time to let others know that there is a good value and great hotel waiting for them at Hotel Vitale.

May 17 2005	Great Hotel in a Great City!	I stayed at this hotel for five nights in May. Without question, this hotel will quickly become one of the most sought after properties in a city filled with great hotels. Its location -- across the street from the Ferry Building on the Embarcadero -- offers immediate access to great food anytime during the week, but especially during Saturdays Farmers Market. I stayed in a room that overlooked the water. It was comfortably decorated and offered plenty of space. Guests can also access several rooftop terraces for a quiet respite above the city. And although the hotel was solid out during my stay, the staff was attentive and extremely courteous. I will certainly make this hotel my second home, whenever I visit San Francisco.

May 5 2005	It doesn't get any better than this!!	We decided to try the Hotel Vitale because we love finding new places to stay. We stayed at the Vitale for 4 nights and the Four Seasons for 2 nights. When we were at the Four Seasons my husband said that he wanted to return to the Vitale!! The bay views at Vitale are incredible, the staff was wonderful and the location was great, next to the beautiful Ferry Building and some of the best restaurants in the city. We ate at the hotel's restaurant "Americano" and enjoyed it very much. I would highly recommend staying here, we LOVED it!!

May 3 2005 	Great location very stylish service needs work	As the other reviews have said, this hotel is in a great location, very stylish, very comfortable, amazing views, etc.The service does have some major issues though. For example, my room keys stopped working after the first night mysteriously. Also, when I called to order room service, and when I got my wake up call, they called me by the wrong last name (after complaining several times, I eventually just got used to it). My dry cleaning which was picked up at 8am was supposed to be back by 7pm the same night, unfortunately they "forgot" about it and had to overnight it for me. A staff member showed up at my door with milk and coffee which I had supposedly ordered (I didn't).When the service does fall through - they make a very vailiant effort to correct the problem, which I respect. But - there shouldn't be SO many problems. And, it's not just my dumb luck - I've talked to several other colleagues who have stayed at this hotel who have had issues.In summary - it's a really great hotel, but they need to work out some operational kinks before it can even be considered as best in class.

May 2 2005	Great hotel... great location!	We recently stayed at Hotel Vitale and found it to be a very nice hotel. The location is perfect with some lovely restaurants and bars very nearby as well as the farmers market across the road selling some amazing organic produce! The room was extremely comfortable with some nice touches altough I was woken 2 nights running with noise from the road. Some slight improvements could be made to turn this into an amazing hotel but we will be back!

Apr 27 2005	Fabulous CA modern style luxurious beds 	Ignore the fact that everyone has said the outside design is a disgrace to the bay skyline. This is a great hotel! The staff was friendly & accomodating at check-in. We had the mushroom & truffle pizza at the Americana and it was very good - a thin, slightly crispy crust, fresh ingredients and that wonderful truffle oil. For $14, we got a 9" pie with 6 slices. The rooms were well dressed and the beds - one word - scrumptous! Down pillows, comforter and enough pillows to make just about anyone happy. We stayed there for a ladies night out and all of us were happy with the rooms. The bathrooms were spacious enough and came with complimentary Fresh Lemon bath products. Reason alone to go there! Ask for extras to take home.Too bad that the rate we got was a special - only $140 for a superior queen room with a view of the bridge and water. But we'll all be back for our next get-together :)

Apr 25 2005	The hot new SF Hotel	Just stayed there for 1 night. Perfect location, great beds. Very very pleasant. The warmth of the hotel, really shines at night. The location makes you get out and explore and exercise. Trully there is a new Gem in Town!I had a massage to top it all off --- Can't wait to go back!

Apr 21 2005	Wonderful stay at the Vitale	Gorgeous rooms, wonderful views of the Bay Bridge and beyond. Subtle, tasteful decor and limestone bathrooms with super toileteries. Excellent service, especially from patient and helpful Edward Kitone. Hotel location a 15 minute walk from Union Square.Dinner at the hotel's Americano restaurant recommended. Also delicious strawberries at breakfast. Can additionally recommend dining at the Slanted Door in the Embecardero Centre.

Apr 21 2005	Beautiful Hotel	We stayed at the Hotel Vitale the weekend it opened. The staff was friendly and helpful. The room was just wonderful: mood lighting, jazz CDs, flat screen TV, spa bathroom, and an incredible view of the Ferry Building, Bay Bridge, and sailboats on the Bay.Dinner at the Americano was great, along with the service. Had an incredible spa treatment. The roof top patio is a very nice place to enjoy a coffee and the view. Would recommend Hotel Vitale for anyone who would like to enjoy a wonderful San Francisco experience!

Apr 20 2005	We thought the property was hip yet elegant	The room ( bedding, bath and view were excellent). The food in the Americano restaurant was wonderful. The ability to walk to the Ferry Plaza was fantastic.We loved the property, and would highly recommend it

Apr 18 2005	Wonderful Hotel Vitale	We had an opporunity to stay at The Vitale in San Francisco CA. The location was fantastic; across from the Embarcadero and the wonderful Ferry Building shops. The rooms were done in a very tasteful modern dcor. My husband loved the latest flat screen TV in our room. The beds were not the run of the mill hotel bed, but the kind you want to take home. I especially appreciated the quietness of the room. The Vitale has a rooftop patio that overlooks the bay where we enjoyed a cup of morning coffee. Dont miss enjoying a wonderful meal at the Americana Restaurant located in the hotel.

Apr 17 2005	A gem on the Embarcadero	We just finished a two-night getaway at the Hotel Vitale, and it was one of the most enjoyable times we have had.We have stayed at Joie de vivre hotels before, and like our experiences before, the staff at these hotels are friendly, courteous, and helpful. (Where they find these folks, I don't know.)The interior is sleek, modern, clean and stark. If you are expecting something traditional in decor, Hotel Vitale may be a little off-putting, but we found it refreshing.The room was immaculate, the bed comfortable, the down pillows enticing. What was especially nice was the simple climate controls that responded quickly and quietly to our requested room environment.Geographically, Hotel Vitale has a great location. Right across the street from the Ferry Building, a block away from the Embarcadero Centerand Market Street, and a world class view of the Bay Bridge. Close enough for me to go on a morning ramble up the Filbert Steps and Coit Tower. A quick plug for an exceptional restaurant only a block away, the Cosmopolitan Cafe. Outstanding food and service that is prescient.The highlight had to be on Saturday morning when we went to the farmers market at the Ferry Building. A beautiful sunshiny S.F. morning, a complete overload on your visual and olafactory senses, a guitarist and fiddler sitting right next to us playing away while Cindi had world class crepes and i had bacon and eggs on a baguette.On the fifth floor of the hotel is a terrace with huge, comfortable chairs and a view of the bridge, Yerba Buena island and the bay. It is wheelchair accessible and after dinner. we went up with a split of champagne and watched all the activity up and down the Embarcadero, on the bay, and the bridge lit up like a fairy tale structure.Two things i found annoying in this wonderful stay. There are no waste baskets on the terrace, so you have to cart any trash back to your room. The second problem is the hotel offers no complmentary coffee in the morning, unless you wanted to call room service at ruinous prices. So every morning I would trot across the street to Peet's (open 5:30 weekdays) to get our coffee. This is not a good thing!All in all, grest time--great stay.Jim Myers

Apr 17 2005	Amazing views wonderful hospitality so relaxing!	We had the privilege of staying at the hotel during the first week of its opening and you'd never know they were all just getting started. Very professional and courteous staff (so friendly!) and the hotel has a great "vibe" to it. Loved being down by the Ferry Building and amazing views of the Bay Bridge. Took advantage of the wonderful spa service before having drinks down in the very comfy bar. The breakfast at Americano the next day made us wish we'd stayed there for dinner instead of wandering across the street to Metro (which was, of course, very good). The rooms were well appointed and had all the nice little touches I've come to love about Joie de Vivre hotels. A shiny new star in their roster!

Apr 14 2005	Wow on the Waterfront!	If the million dollar water views don't get you (be sure to request a room facing the bay), then the casual elegance of all of the amenities will - the subtle and soothing decor, a fabulously comfortable bed, the flat screen TV, dimmer lighting in the bathroom, a rainforest showerhead - just to name a few. Walk the hallways and inhale the essence of lavendar as small sprays are placed next to each guestroom door. All the little details make for a relaxing (including outside soaking tubs on the top floor, along with a luxurious spa) and memorable stay, but it was that phenomenal bay view that will take your breath away - location, location, location!

Apr 14 2005	Loved Hotel Vitale	I found the hotel to have a wonderfully calming feel to it. The only fault I could find was that there was no coffee available in the morning in the lobby. I twould be nice to have complimentary coffee and or tea in the available. The rooms are very well appointed and the beds, incredibly comfortable. I know that the hotel will be a welcome addition to the Financial district of San Francisco.

Apr 14 2005	What a refreshing experience in San Francisco!	I surprised my husband with a weekend stay at Hotel Vitale. A brand-new Joie de Vivre Hotel in San Francisco. -- What a refreshing experience! The atmosphere is naturally sophisticated and cozy. Urban yet natural. It's a boutique hotel with deluxe full services. --An A+ on my list! This place has a privileged and unique location, right across form the new Ferry Building ( where the new Farmer's Market is ) on the Embarcadero Area. A five minute cab ride from Union Square, ( the shopping district ). Their water front rooms and circular suites have unbeatable views of the water and the Bay Bridge. ( You can actually see three San Francisco landmarks from their terraces! ) Their restaurant "Americano" is innovative, delicious and fresh. Very California, very San Francisco! We loved the ambiance of the bar and the crowd. It was refreshing to stay in a place that feels very San Francisco, but in a very unique and refreshing way. If you stay for more than one night and want to try other restaurants, the famous and established "Boulevard" is right across the street, and having lunch at the Ferry Building is a must! And the best part: Hotel Vitale has an attentive friendly and professional staff. It has the feel of a world class hotel, but without the stuffiness or the attitude!

Apr 14 2005	Room with a Spectacular View!	My stay at the new Hotel Vitale was nothing less than amazing! I have stayed at many hotels throughout the country and in San Francisco as well and the Hotel Vitale was refreashing with wonderful Bay Bridge and water views from the public areas as well as the rooms. We enjoyed the restaurant within the hotel, the sevice was excellent and the food was superb! It was a great experience!

Apr 14 2005	Loved the Vitale!	Hotel Vitale is a beautiful new hotel in great area of San Francisco - right across the street from the bay along the Embarcadero. The rooms have great views, nice bedding and big bathrooms. You can also find amazing food in the hotel's restaurant. We had a fantastic time and are recommending it to all our friends.

Apr 14 2005	Great getaway in San Francisco	The hotel is located along the beautiful SF Waterfront with views of the Bay Bridge and a stones throw away from the newly restored Ferry Building and Plaza. The rooms are comfortable with top of the line amenities that add such an nice touch to the overall experience.

Apr 13 2005	Nice but maybe too expensive?	I am actually a resident of San Francisco, but every once and a while my spouse and I like to pamper ourselves by spending a night in a luxury hotel to get a break from our dull apartment.We have always had great experiences with the hotels run by Joie de Vivre Hospitality, so we decided to give the new Hotel Vitale a try. Because the hotel was offering specials for its grand opening, we decided to splurge on a Deluxe Waterfront King Room, which was $259 for the night (normally $309). We were checked in fairly quickly, but unfortunately did not get a room on one of the higher floors, which would have afforded more expansive views of the water and Bay Bridge. As with other JDV hotels, the room was of a smart design with the most comfortable bed and bedding you could imagine. The room was smaller than I had imagined but adequate, and I was disappointed to find no bathtub. The room description online indicated that the bathroom was a "spa style" bathroom with a "rain" shower head. The rain shower head was great, but I expected there would be a tub as well.The other downside of the room was the traffic noise that could be heard from the street. The obvious trade off of facing the busy Embarcadero St. is the view of the bay, etc., but light sleepers might be annoyed by the traffic noise. The Embarcadero typically quiets down in the late evening hours, but the occasional bus and truck could be heard throughout the night.My favorite part of the hotel (besides the incredible bed) was its location. If I were a tourist, I would prefer this location right across the street from the Ferry Building as opposed to those hotels found in Union Square. It's easy to get to either Union Square or Fisherman's Wharf from this hotel via various forms of mass transportation or simply by walking if you don't mind a 20 to 30 minute walk. There are numerous fine dining restaurants within the immediate vicinity of the hotel, including Boulevard....one of the city's best restaurants. And if you're a baseball fan, it's conveniently located within a mile of SBC park.Overall, I would recommend this hotel if you can afford it. The service from the staff was excellent....quick to respond when you need it; invisible when you don't.

Apr 11 2005	Nothing Spectacular	I have to say, I was not terribly impressed with the Hotel Vitale by any means. We've definitely experienced worse, but by no means do I think this place is anything spectacular - or worthy of four stars. If you're just looking for a reasonably clean hotel, and aren't looking for 4 Seasons level service - this place should fit the bill. If you want some more dirt, read on...Decor alone - high marks for sure. Great linens, and overall comfy, understated elegance. Nice touch was the lavendar sprigs they put on each door for bedtime.Location - across from the Embarcadero and all was great, but overall it is a pretty desolate area on the weekends with no where in walking distance to grab a coffee, etc. Overall, from a service standpoint, I think it was marginal at best and bound to slide more if this is just the honeymoon phase...We booked for Friday and Saturday night (4/8 and 4/9). My husband had called ahead the day before we had arrived and requested a cot for our 11 year old daughter. The person he spoke with indicated it would not be a problem and told him to mention it upon check-in. We checked in around 8:30pm on Friday and mentioned the cot to the reception desk. They had indicated it would not be a problem and would be arranged by the time we returned from dinner. We got back to the hotel at 11:30 - exhausted and ready to hit the hay, suprise - no cot! Because we were so exhausted and because we're really not complainers, we decided to squeeze into the king bed - which I have to say, was quite comfy with great linens, duvet, etc. We opted not to park our rental car at the hotel - just under $50 a day or so (there is a parking garage about a block away for 1/2 that)- and instead took cabs. Never once was there someone ready and waiting to hail a cab as you would come to expect from 4 star hotel. Day 2 - we returned to our hotel (having spent the entire day sightseeing, shopping, etc) at 10:30pm only to have our keys not work. Having read the other review where somone's room was given to someone else, I have to say, we were a little concerned. We went back down to reception, got our new keys (no sincere apologies or explanation) and got back into our room - luckily, all our stuff was there!Day 3 - we waited in line to check out (because they had incorrectly billed us for valet parking which we'd passed on) for about 15 minutes. The best part is the people at the desk were answering phones and accepting reservations while they were trying to check people out. On a Sunday morning, I cannot for the life of my understand how they would be busying themselves with reservations while there are people trying to check out!

Apr 6 2005 	I'm picky but this place was great	I left after a terrible experience at a hotel down the street and found this great hotel. It had just opened. The staff was helpful and friendly. The room was large and with great windows. Many city hotels are claustraphobic, but this one was spacious. The hotel is modern, but it manages to still feel homey. You have all the amenities. Rather than having a small corner to work, you have a great desk. The Dean and Deluca snacks in the mini bar are a great touch.I had a massage in the new spa. It is small but very nice. I plan to go back again and highly recommend it. This comes from someone that is quite picky about hotels.

Apr 5 2005	Truly Luxury Naturally.	I stayed at the Hotel Vitale on Saturday, April 2, in one of the panoramic suites. I've never stayed in such a room... the attention to detail and design were amazing... great bathroom products (a great break from Aveda), healthy snacks/bar, automatic window shutters, sound machine, long working desk with office chair, very comfortable bed/pillows, iPod speaker system, dvd player, flat screen tv, interesting magazines, unique services and amenities offered, regular and rain drop shower heads in glass faced walk-in shower with wooden stool, two sinks in separate toilet/shower rooms, mini bar, Bose alarm clock, sofa and chair, bath tub by the window, 270 degree views, circular room design, etc. You must experience this room.As far as customer service went, it was excellent... everyone is super helpful/friendly (and presentable) and although the hotel has a stylish, hip feel, you feel comfortable and not pressed to "be cool". And when you check out, you really do feel like you had a relaxing stay. The spa/wellness, natural theme should appeal to all types of travelers. The Americano (Italian) restaurant complements the hotel well, too. In my opinion, it is a great date place because of its reasonable prices, classy/stylish feel and opportunity for pre and after dinner drinks in either the long bar area or circular lounge. Lastly, you can't really beat this location. It is along the Embarcadero/water and across from the Ferry Building/Farmer's Market... a great place to hang out during the day, for food, exercise, sights, etc.Hotel Vitale should be THE place to stay from here on out. Definitely, luxury, naturally.

glad i cancelled	after reading some very disturbing reviews i decided to cancel our stay and even that was a mission, 10 minute hold and a rude person at the end of the line when i finally go to speak to someone! lucky escape

Nov 22 2009	Not the Best place....but	If it hadn't have been for Shaunda, we would have asked for a refund. First room had MOLD growing up the side of the wall (which is a serious health department violation, so I hope they fixed it!)...asked for a different room and then the tv in the 2nd room didn't work. Shaunda definitely took care of us, though! Burnie, however, needs a SERIOUS attitude adjustment! He was more than rude to us on the checkout when there were questions about parking during exit. He obviously needs to get another job. I almost asked for the manager because it was unacceptable how he treated us.Upgrades need to be made on the rooms. Most of them are very small and you feel a little cramped. Old outlets, fixtures, rusty toilet paper dispensers, older light fixtures. Yes, the manager will reply to this review and say it's the "historic charm" of the place...but charm can also require a few updates, too. However, for the price it's almost worth the value. Location is not the best but not horrible either. Aug 2 2009 	Clean Comfortable Convenient	The Hotel Whitcomb is a great hotel at a bargain price. I am a clean freak, and this hotel was very clean. There were no bugs....bed or any other kind. The furniture is dated, but we did not care. The beds were comfortable. TV was great/ If there was anything we needed, the staff was extremely prompt in responding to our requests. Our room had a huge closet where we stored our luggage, so we had plenty of room to move around. There is air and heat in the room, contrary to other reviews. Our room faced Market Street, and we did hear the traffic, but we were really just in our room to regroup and sleep, so it wasn't a big deal. If you are a light sleeper, request a room that does not face Market Street, or take ear plugs. Les concierge were fabulous, Jan and Ryan. There is a little gift shop with some necessities, also. There were homeless people everywhere we went, not just outside the Whitcomb. In fact, there were very few homeless people outside the Whitcomb, and we felt very safe. It's a great location with public transportation right outside the hotel.We did a lot in San Francisco. The Whitcomb is across the street from the Orpheum where Wicked is showing. If you go over there around 5:00 PM, you can put your name to be drawn in a lottery for two tickets (Orchestra seats!) for $25 each ticket. My daughter won, so we sent my son and daughter to the musical. They had a great time! You can try each day. Be sure you have ID, and if you have a child under 17, you can vouch for him/her. Each person in your family can put his/her name in for the drawing.Buy the pass and get to know public transportation. You do not need a car. San Francisco was great! Eat across the street at Sam's. Good food and attentive servers....I would definitely recommend Hotel Whitcomb, and I am very picky.

Jun 4 2009 	Solid hotel with a good price tag	This was my second stay in Hotel Whitcomb and my experience is practically the same. If going to the convention center it will cost you around $7 to go by Taxi, or you can use the bus via the station that is located just in front of the hotel. By foot will take you around 10-15 minutes, but I wouldn't suggest walking after the sun sets down, as it could be a bit "creepy" with all the people on the streets...The hotel was nice, the hallways look like Kubrick's The Shining was shot there, which was definitely a plus for me. I know that this is one of the older hotels there, but they should "update" these things.I forgot the name of the restaurant in the hotel, but I remember it was much better the previous year. Jun 4 2009 	Wonderful Hotel at a great bargain. Bus and street-car stop is right ouitside the hotel on Market street. "F" street-car takes you all the way down to the warf area and all the way back to hotel!! Wonderful hands-on science exhibits for all ages. My 2-year old LOVED this place! Have your friends see you live over the Exploratorium webcam when you stand at the entrance.  I really enjoyed visiting the Nike Missle Base Museum SF88 across the bay and walking around the old gun battery emplacements overlooking the bay. Nike bas is open wed-fri, but special open house is 1st saturday of every month.

Jun 1 2009 	Great Value Price Service...Good Location..	A friend and I stayed at this Hotel from May 9-May 14th. We paid 99 dollars/night for the room. (two doubles).We had no problems with the cleaning staff. The rooms were always cleaned, supplies refreshed, and everything in its proper place. Check in and check out were a breeze, and the service at the front desk was excellent. We wanted to split our bill in half, and that was easily accommodated.The location of this hotel is a double edged sword. On the one hand, it has a MUNI and a BART stop right in front of the hotel. ( San Frans local and regional transit system respectively). This means you can get from the airport to the hotel for under 6 dollars one way, and not have to go far to use the MUNI ( local transit system). It is close to downtown, Union Square, all the shopping, etc by transit, and it is walkable.*but more on that later* It is extremely close to United Nations Plaza (where there is farmer's market 2 times a week). And did I mention the Starbucks in the lobby of the hotel?The decor of the hotel is beautiful, as well as the rooms. The Lobby is particularly impressive.On the downside...this hotel is located just south of Tenderloin, a gritty, sketchy area of San Francisco. There are homeless people, and there are vagrants who will beg for money. I'm not sure if I'd recommend this hotel for my sister (if she were travelling alone), and I sure as heck wouldn't want her walking to the hotel at night. Again, because the transit stops right outside, that concern is mitigated. In short, I'd be ok walking to and from this hotel in the day, and early evening. At night, I'd be very alert, not want to be walking for more than 15 mins, or just take transit back. Due to the stop right outside the door...transit is a cheap and convenient option.However, because of the neighbourhood, the hotel is cheaper than it should be...if that makes sense. The same hotel, in another area, would easily be twice as expensive, if not more.Internet access was available in the lobby, as well as a fitness centre.Would I stay in this hotel again? For the price I paid, YES. The service was great, the rooms clean, and all the advantages of its location ( transit, closeness to downtown, etc), easily outweigh the fact that it's ON THE BORDER ( not even IN a sketchy part of town). If you're used to an urban environment, and all the social problems that can come with it ( such as homelessness), this hotel and environment should pose no concerns to you.

May 20 2009 	Decent basic level accommodation in an expensive city	We only stayed one night here on honeymoon before going on a week's trip to Hawaii and simply wanted somewhere not very expensive to spend a night. In this regard the hotel fitted the bill. The room was old fashioned and basic, and reasonably clean. The amenities were not as good as I'd like though. We arrived from the airport late at night and I was very thirsty and wanted a drink, but the only option (there was no hotel bar open and no minibar) was to wander the floors looking for a vending machine/ice machine. There was only 1 on each floor and the first couple I found were broken so I had to visit several floors just to get a drink. To get food we had to call a delivery company for a pizza. The location is quite "interesting", not far from some of the dodgy areas of SF, so you wouldn't want to wonder around outside at night. During the day it's fine although you will likely get beggers asking for money if you're obviously a tourist. I asked the hotel if they would store a spare suitcase (we didn't need all our luggage in Hawaii) for the week we were away and they refused to do so. They said they didn't have anywhere to store it, which seems pretty hard to believe in such a huge building. So instead we asked the Hotel Kabuki (where we stayed on our return) if they would do this and they were more than happy to help. So a definite black mark against the Whitcomb and a gold star to the Kabuki. Upon check-out I would say that the hotel were good in that they helped me do an online check-in for our flight from their business room. Overall this hotel was adequate in that it gave us a fairly cheap place to spend a night. However I thought the overall experience/lack of facilities matched the price we paid and therefore I would only recommend it to those travelling on a tight budget.

May 12 2009 	Bad location decent rooms	We stayed at the Whitcomb hotel since it's location on the map was great. But if you like to hang out with crackheads and give a lot of change to homeless people, this is the location for you!

May 4 2009 	Reasonable price and easy commuting	I stayed there over the Christmas of 2008. The place is in downtown. I can access to a lot of places by using the public transportation. The room and bathroom is small however they are clean and neat. At night, you will see a lot of homeless people on street. However, those public transportation are very close to the hotel. When you walk out from subway/train, the hotel is right on the side. At first I was kind of scare with the homeless people, but then later on I realize that they do not bother tourists.The moment when I walked into the hotel, I feel safe and the security guards are doing a good job in keep the place safe for the people who stay in there. You can get Starbucks coffee in the morning because the store is in the hotel.I am not the type of person who demand a lot from room service. I just need a room to sleep and my room has to be cleaned everyday. To me, I think they did their best. The staffs in the hotel are friendly and approachable. Their check-in and check-out are easy and fast.I would recommend people who is on the budget in traveling and looking for a place to stay. Apr 30 2009 	Location location...-	We stayed at this place April 09. Pros: rate was $99/night! double bed, good mattresses, clean. Cons: small/utilitarian bathroom, very noisy evry night till about 2 AM ( firefighters, police, ambulances) as we were on Market St side although on the 6th floor. First night we had a couple yelling and beating each other until wee hours of the morning, it gives you an idea about phonic insulation. Biggest drawback was the distance- 15-17 min walking- to the cable car and the fact that the area is unsafe after 7-8 PM ( You do have a choice to take the street car). We like to walk a lot on foot to know a place however people with bizzare behavior will approach you , etc, not a pleasant experience especially when you are in vacation. Weekends are worse because all bussinesses are shut down. Altogether the hotel itself couldn't compensate for the decrepit surroundings. Apr 30 2009 	A good place to stay in San Francisco	This is a really lovely hotel and the staff are very obliging and polite - and the bed very comfortable!! It has bags of character.It is situated about a 10 minute walk from Union Square and 3 minutes from City HallThe immediate surrounding area is a little grim but nothing to worry about. It is easy to get to Fishermans Wharf from here by just jumping on a bus. Also you can easily get to the airport from here as the station is more or less outside the hotel. It is about half an hour on the train and costs $6.I would definitely recommend this hotel.

Apr 23 2009 	A Day in San Francisco...	Arrived in the city around 10am and we were able to park our car in the lot early. The staff (valet, front desk, restaurant) was very polite and helpful. Excellent service. After sightseeing for most of the afternoon we went back to the hotel to check in. Our room was on the 6th floor facing Market. A little noisy with the windows open, but the weather was on the cool side so once the windows were closed it was very quiet. Clean room, and quite spacious for a SF hotel. We requested a queen but ended up with 2 doubles- which was fine because we were only there for one night. If you are planning on seeing a play at the Orpheum this hotel is VERY convenient. We saw Wicked in the evening and the walk back to the hotel was about 2 minutes- which is a good thing because it's not the best of neighborhoods. During the day it's fine but I wouldn't walk too far at night. If you don't mind walking this is a great hotel because it's not far from Union Square and other popular areas of SF.

Apr 20 2009 	wonderful whitcomb	we stayed for 3 nights at the end of a trip to california.we booked this hotel mainly due to its location to the public transport links as we wanted to get around as quickly as possible to see as much of sf as we could. the bart/train station was as near as you could get, just outside the door - making an easy trip from the airport. there is also a tram and bus stop outside.on arrival we were greeted with a smile and checked into our room immediately. sure the rooms aren't huge but it was clean and just what we wanted - kingsize bed, tv and good size closet to put our 3 huge cases in. the only bad points were lack of kettle/coffee making service (probably due to starbucks next door) and very poor internet connection - we really struggled to get a connection and had to have the laptop in a specific spot without moving it).the concierge/doorman was very helpful with our questions on how to get to different places and was never without a smile or a song. in fact all staff we encountered were most helpful and most importantly were very friendly -(i am aware the manager regularly reviews these reviews and if he reads this, would like him to pass our thanks to all staff working 9th - 12th april who made our stay a great one).the hotel had a lovely old fashioned feel to it and had more character than most motels/hotels we had stayed in. it was within very easy walking distance to all the main shops and the cable car at powell street and only 30mins to the ferrys for alcatraz! the golden gate bridge was a bit of a bigger journey but well worth it. as was the golden gate park - we got a cab there for bout $11, where we went to the japanese tea garden which was beautiful.sure there are homeless people in the area making it daunting out at night - but it is in the centre of a big city and i would expect this could be seen anywhere in the world - you just need to make sure you know where you're going at night and not to flash cash or valuables. we walked back from a bar in the financial district one evening without anyone approaching us at all. there was always a member of staff in the lobby from early evening so it was very safe. we loved our stay here which made our experience to sf a wonderful one and cannot wait to return.

Apr 17 2009 	Simply Amazing.	The Hotel Whitcomb is always an amazing stay. I travel to San Francisco a lot, and I always stay here. There is a man by the name of Rolando who works at the front desk, he always helps me out, gets me checked in and ready to go. And is one of the best staff members I have ever seen. Apr 13 2009 	Beautiful hotel right on mass transit line	The Hotel Whitcomb was a welcome sight - a beautiful older hotel that I love in San Francisco. My husband said "Wow" when he saw the pictures. The best food and shopping in the area is about 5 blocks away at the San Francisco center. The service was great, but the beds were a little too firm. Apr 12 2009 	Great Stay at The Hotel Whitcomb	My boyfriend and I had a great stay here. Very friendly service from all of the hotel staff, especially the front desk. We had a very cute room. Mar 11 2009 	BDay Extravaganza!!!!	A couple of my best girlfriends and I stayed at the Hotel Whitcomb for my birthday and it was completely fabulous. Mar 9 2009 	Looking for a value hotel?? Choose the Whitcomb!!	I'm currently staying the Whitcomb in one of the Petite Double rooms. Mar 8 2009 	Perfect Location for the City	A friend and myself visited San Francisco for 4 days. We booked rooms at the Whitcomb through Orbitz and had a very reasonable rate for staying in the City. The hotel is classic and the rooms were quite nice with high ceilings and fully furnished. The bathrooms are huge. It is an historic hotel and with that you would expect high ceilings and larger rooms and that is what you get. At check in, I requested rooms at the front of the hotel overlooking Market St. I am so glad I did that. We both had rooms with a view of City Hall and at night it was wonderful to have this view. As is typical of older city hotels, this hotel does have rooms that overlook nothing or a wall. Always ask for rooms at the front of the building. The Starbucks in the lobby is quite nice and the service is totally fast Starbucks. Other people here have reviewed this hotel and complained about the homeless population around the hotel. Well, guess what? There are homeless everywhere in San Francisco, this is NOT a reflection of this hotel. The neighborhood is safe and equal to any in the City. The transportation outside the front door is wonderful, you can go ANYWHERE in the City from this hotel front door. My encounters with the concierge desk were wonderful. They were friendly and quite helpful, AND they knew what they were talking about. There was no "Hmm, I don't know". It was like staying in a hotel in Europe for me, the hallways were huge, so old style. And the elevators were there in seconds. They all worked and did the job well. The staff was friendly and helpful. Thank you for a nice stay. Only problem I could come up with is that the internet service seem to be overwhelmed, so slow to download, but that is the fault of the service that they contract with, they could try another service. And I was on the 6th floor and the ice machine was missing, so I had to hoof it to the 5th or 7th floor for ice. But maintenance is maintenance.

Mar 4 2009	More luxurious than you would expect from a 3-star hotel.	Beautiful hotel and in a very convenient location. Ridiculous. I explained that I did not pocess a credit/debit card and they were trying to put it on my friends card, who luckily did not the excess of $1000. So avoid any embaressing restaurant moments when your card is rejected, as the hotel has your money! Also be aware of them charging $220 for smoking in your room. I must admit that the smell in my hotel corridor could me high from suspect substances being smoked alone. My room for myself was fine for all the time I was in it. Cleaned everyday, fresh towels, sheets etc replaced. Had no complaints about that. Remember first time visitors the hotel is not greatly placed, very near the avoidable Tenderloin across the road. Do not go if the homeless upset you. Found no hassle though. If this comes up as a bargin again I may think about but I'd go for an apartment to share with friends in Telegraph hill the next time. Worked out just a bit more for comfort, worth a look. Go to Lou's on the square in Washington Sq. for great cocktails and company, she's an awesome trooper.

Jan 6 2009 	Know what you pay for.	My boyfriend and I stayed here during a stop on our road trip down the coast. I paid about $70 for a non-smoking room with a queen bed, which was advertised as 50% off the original price (~$140) on Hotels.com the week after Thanksgiving 2008. I thought, "Wow...it's 50% off and it's a historic hotel. I'm there." I checked the reviews on TripAdvisor and saw that it recieved mediocre reviews mostly due to its poor parking situation and room conditions. I thought I'd give it a go anyway.A few days before I was supposed to arrive at Hotel Whitcomb, I called to push my reservation back a day. That was easy. I checked to see what its current rates were after I hung up. My room was still going for about $70 at regular price! I got duped. I'm usually good about recognizing a phony "sale", but this time I didn't.Here's the fun part - figuring out where to park when you DO get to the hotel! First of all, San Francisco is disorienting. There was no where for us to stop the car and see where either the public parking or valet was. There were no plainly posted signs! After circling around for awhile trying to find parking, my boyfriend, who was driving, tried the alley between Hotel Whitcomb and the building next door. It took us right to valet parking! Whitcomb needs to put a sign somewhere, seriously. After that fun experience, we figured we'd pay the $28/day for valet. At the registrars desk is a sign that says valet is $28/day plus tax...its website never mentioned tax! I was determined to keep an open mind about the rest of the hotel. The lobby level looks nice. There is antique looking furniture (or at least non-pressboard with veneer furniture) and many chandeliers. The elevators have a special ding when the doors open. The room (at least ours) looked fitting for a historic hotel room. Though, upon closer inspection I noticed the furniture was pressboard with veneer. Don't let this deter you. I was expecting there to be furniture from the time period it was built. (I stayed at a historic house in York, England that had antique furniture.) Expecting antique furniture for a $70 room (in a hotel with 460 rooms) wasn't realistic.My real beef with the room was there was one washcloth (for two registered guests...we had to call the front desk twice the first of two nights to get them to bring more and they still only left one the second night), the space around the sink faucet wasn't clean and had a hair stuck to it (I cleaned it myself), the bathroom door wouldn't shut because the latch was stuck in the door, there were stains on our blanket duvet, and no free breakfast (not even continental) was offered. Also, down the hall from us were a group of college-aged looking people who were noisy (and we are 23 ourselves!)One good thing that sort of counterbalanced some of the bad, was the concierge. Michelle, who is the gift shop cashier and the hotel concierge, is fantastic! She grew up in San Francisco and knows it quite well. She knows what's worth seeing and what's plain touristy. She can make a public transportation route based on your activities for the day. Even though SF's public transportation is really good, it was really confusing. Michelle's help was valuable because my boyfriend and I only had one day in SF and we hadn't done much research.So here's the breakdown...1. If you plan on driving here, know the parking situation.2. Don't expect much for $70.3. Don't expect elegancy. Though it portrays itself as elegant, it is not - evidenced by the staff's and the hotel resident's mannerisms, and also by the homeless outside.4. The cleanliness is iffy inside the rooms.Remember...do research before chosing any hotel, motel, inn, B&B, etc.!

Jan 5 2009	Nedd a hotel in San Fran? try this one!!!	Recently traveled to San Fran & while The Hotel Whitcombe is not in the upmarket area of this great city, this hotel is still great value. It situated near what I think is called the Tenderloin district we are a couple of what are called OLDIES & we were never harassed or had a problem with the street people.. We were able to walk down to Union Sq in such a short time to dine,shop or just check the city out on foot.. Transport is right outside hotel all is easy to get around with.. Special mention to our favourite diner SAMS opposite great for breakfast or late snacks. Cheap to dine as well, service is pleasant nice friendly staff. sadly we cant remember the lovely Korean owners name but she was tops.we wish them well..If your going to San Francisco GO PAY A VISIT you will be rrewarded.. Dec 24 2008	Did not like Whitcomb	Just spent five nights in Whitcomb, San Francisco. Go for Whitcomb if you can't afford anything better (although it is not much cheaper). And location...yes, it is right next to BART and MUNI station and bus and street car stops and five min away from Asian museum, but within a homeless peoples' vicinity....they come for cofee or just for warmth to the Starbacks accessable from the hotel's lobby...honestly, not too pleasant....

Dec 22 2008 	Mixed Review	Stayed at Hotel Whitcomb for 4 nights. Was somehow upgraded to a suite which was a nice surprise. However, it was a corner room and a bit noisey...it is in the heart of San Francisco but I was glad I brought sleeping pills. Read other reviews regarding location and yes it is on the edge of the tenderloin but if Castro was your destination there is no problem or the City Hall area just don't walk to Union square or directly behind the hotel.Another small problem on the third day was an accidental fall in the bathtub. The tubs are really old and very worn which results in a very slick surface. It looked as if this may have happened before as there were several holes where it seemed the shower curtain was rehung and tile missing. I told the front desk they needed to rehang the shower curtain and bring a rubber bathmat. This took two calls. Told the manager on the last day and he was nice enough to offer a complimentary breakfast but we were leaving that morning. For the AAA special it was well worth it just watch the tubs or call for a mat.

Dec 2 2008 	Kinda Nice But....	This is a hotel designated as a "Historic Hotel of America" and I won't argue with that but be warned that this is a building needing a bit of a renovation. The service of the staff was fine however walking to our room I was kind of struck by the moldy/mildew smell of the hallways. The room was nice, although being over Market St we at times felt like the traffic and street sounds were in our room. Light sleepers beware! The bathroom was big and had the look of having been partially renovated in the 70s. The loose tiles, mildew on the caulking made you think a newer renovation was due. Lastly, and other commentors have said this, Market Street at this spot in particular isn't pretty. Having to dodge the panhandlers each day was a hassle and in the evening seeing an obvious prostitute hanging in front of the entrance kind of made me wince. I recommend that if you have a choice stay in a SF neighborhood away from downtown. Public transportation is great in SF and that is where SF looks and feels best.

Nov 21 2008 	Genuinely neat place!	I can honestly say that I have probably spent more nights in the Whitcomb than any person on the planet! As a result of my responsibilities with a large event at the end of june in SF, I am fortunate to have the Whitcomb to call home for nearly a month each year (for 9 years now!)The StaffThe Whitcomb has the friendliest hotel staff in SF! Though my visits are typically 11 months apart, the front desk staff actually remembers my name! Olga and Kazi are the best, they continually go out of their way to make me feel welcome (even though my stays are sometimes at a financial loss to the property) Check In has always been a breeze and the few times i've had requests they've been handled expeditiously. The Propertywhile i agree with some reviewers that the hotel's location isnt ideal, i've never been made to feel unsafe. i routinely walk from the property to locations throughout Civic Center Plaza and have come back to the property as late as 3am on occasion and never felt threatened. The hotel does and incredible job of being a "diamond in the rough" Additionally, with the Orpheum theater directly accross the street its not un common to see people dressed to the nines milling about at late hours when the shows get out. Also i had the incredible fortune of being at the hotel when they were holding rehersal for Hairspray the musical in the ballroom off the lobby... What an opportunity to hear worldclass performers rehearsing!! Also, if you so desire - the Burger King across the street is an unusual but fun place to get an autograph or two after the shows as you almost ALWAYS find hungry actors and actresses there after their performance next door at the orpheum. That being said - if you have a desire to get out of the civic center to the more heavily populated tourist areas, you literally have an entrance to MUNI and BART at your doorstep. While many reviewers have mentioned the availability of the F street car its much more practical to grab BART or the MUNI underground. You'll find that the MUNI underground is much faster than the F street car. You can literally grab any "inbound" muni from the hotel and be in Union Square in 2 min (the next stop inbound from the hotel is Powell) the best part is it only costs $1.50! If you want to go up to Fishermans Wharf you can always MUNI to Powell and grab a cable car there for an aweful lot of fun! Basically you get the benefits of staying in an overpriced tourist trap in union square or SOMA or Embarcadaro without the steep price I really see this as a major pro not a con at all!!The RoomsI cant speak highly enough about the comfort of the rooms. If you are looking for marble bathrooms and granite counters look elsewhere, but if you are looking for a clean comfortable room with old San Francisco charm then this is the place for you. The beds are amongst the most comfortable i've ever slept in and the bathrooms are functional. Every room i've stayed in (and i've stayed in plenty!!) have oversized clostes. Each room has a desk and some have a side table and reading type chair as well. All of the rooms have a nice bright paint job and remind me of boutique hotels in downtown london. Honestly, this place isnt the Ritz but you get amazing value at this world class property. Hang out in the lobby if you get the chance and take in the amazing marble and crystal chandaliers. Grab a bite and a drink at the Market Street Grill (their crab cakes are great!)

Nov 18 2008 	great hotel	was a bit worried as we had read bad reviews but i think they must of been at a different hotel went there for our 25 wedding anniversary staff were lovely and very helpful security at night was good lovely room kept lovely and clean great location very handy for bart there was homeless but we never felt threatened overall a lovely stay and would definitly stay again thanks for a lovely two weeks

Nov 12 2008 	Great hotel for an excellent price	I stayed at the Hotel Whitcomb for 4 nights in Jan 08 and I was quite impressed with the hotel.I had been in San Francisco a few times before, so I knew exactly what the area was like, I had often considered staying at the hotel when it was a Ramada.Check-in was rather painless, which was good as I had just gotten off a flight from Dublin via London and was pretty wrecked. My bags were still in London, which didn't really put me in the best of moods.My first impression of the room and the corridors was that it was an old hotel, but was well looked after. The room itself was fine and the bathroom was also fine, if a bit small.I was on a 2 city holday, San Francisco and Las Vegas, so my 4 days were split into 1 day before going to Las Vegas and 3 after returning from Las Vegas.The hotel is right beside an F-line stop, which is handy for getting to Fishermans Wharf etc.There was a slight problem on my return to the hotel after my trip to Vegas due to the fact that due to me turning up a day late, my reservation had actually been cancelled, however, the receptionist was able to find the reservation and re-activate it.The Starbucks in the hotel was also very handy, as I was able to get a Machiato before getting on the tram for Pier 39Overall, I would recommend this hotel and I am considering staying here again on my next trip to San Francisco.

Nov 10 2008	comfortable but...	well...in general, it looks like a pretty nice and comfortable hotel...the goods:-comfortable bed, clean room...the bads:- however, this hotel is located on the 8th street...which is the zone bordering the more sleezy/dodgy area in SF city...every night we'll hear police cars, ambulances, fire engines zooming past...- one night, while i was unpacking with my girlfriend..we heard this 3 loud thumps on the door! and there was no one! *creepy*- the room + toilet had wallpapers that were tearing off...revealed some old yellowish stained wallpapers...when we left the hotel, that's when we realised...the hotel has been gazetted as a heritage monument type building...and 40 years ago...it was a hospital-cum-mortuary!!!! YIKES! and it's common that people hear footsteps and someone calling them in the middle of the night! DOUBLE YIKES!!now i'm wondering whether the loud knocks on the wall was even human...*gulp*

Nov 2 2008 	Credit Crunch Whitcomb	OK so after reviewing some of the comments made here I opted to book the Whitcomb and would not raise expectations. As a frequent business traveller and no stranger to staying in a whole raft of hotels I was not phased by this room, 2 queen beds a walk in wardrobe, free Wi-Fi and a ...... bathroom with no blinds, yes I had a room that overlooked Market street and the bathroom window also had a view of Market Street, OK the window was frosted but I had no desire to shower (no tub) for the viewing public. I asked the front desk if there was another room and was told that I had one of the best rooms as it was a disabled persons room and were generally bigger than others. The area as expected was rather seedy and as such one did not wonder past the front doors after dark, Starbucks was a life saver as was the free Wi-Fi and I elected to stay one night and made use of the Wi-Fi to find an alernative hotel for the remainder of my 5 days. Rounding up the hotel does what it says on the tin, if you are here on a budget and are not too worried about the neighbour hood then you should have a reasonable time at the Whitcomb. I do however urge the managment to address some basic needs as the rooms are tired and could do with some refurbishment in keeping with the hotels history, I would also like to see the Citys authorities be pro-active in sorting out the homeless folk outside and the surrounding area its a real shame as this is a real problem

Nov 2 2008 	Nice Old Hotel Not a great area	Got a good rate through Priceline and got into our room at 11:30 amso was pleased with that.Room was very clean and wireless worked wellStaff was friendly and helpful with tour options etc.Lots of homeless persons around but no one bothered us. Nov 1 2008 	Good but not superb	The service at the hotel was good. The room was spacious and clean. The bathroom was not very big, but it was clean. Oct 31 2008 	Don't go out at night.	I booked this hotel because of the reasonable price and close proximity to public transportation. Like many other reviewers, my husband and I were both concerned about the location, particularly the panhandlers and some somewhat unsavory street vendors on Market St. near the hotel. A friend who has lived in San Francisco for a couple of years described the neighborhood as somewhere where "you are safe during the day, but stay in a group at night." That seemed fair enough. Keep your bag close to you, and be prepared to say "Not today," to a range of people attempting to get your money through begging or selling things you really don't want (poorly written homeless activism newspapers, bootleg hip hop CDs, etc.).That being said, the access to public transportation makes it such that it's relatively easy to avoid these problems with a little planning ahead. The Civic Center BART station and the F Train (which will take you to Union Square, Fisherman's Wharf, Ferries and Castro) are within a few feet of the hotel door, and once you are on the train or in the station, you have much less to worry about. The hotel is between 8th and 9th streets, and I found that if you get off at the 9th St. F Train platform, you had to deal with fewer problems on the streets themselves. What a difference a block makes.I had a few minor concerns about the hotel itself. It could have been cleaner. There were some suspect things on the floor of the bathroom that weren't cleaned until I made sure to leave a towel on top of them so that they would be picked up with the towels. We were there for six nights, and on two of them we had to request wash rags and a bathmat, because housekeeping only left towels and hand towels in the bathroom. Housekeeping was relatively prompt about bringing these items when we requested them, but you really shouldn't have to request things like linens in a hotel.That being said, overall the rooms were tastefully appointed. I have stayed in nicer rooms, but I've also stayed in much less savory places. The staff were always friendly and courteous, and they were quick to refund our money when we had difficulty using the Internet Cafe area.

Oct 27 2008 	Very scary area and rude staff	When I booked this hotel, I realized that the area would not be great, but I didn't realize that I would actually be scared walking around by myself. I live in a big city and am very comfortable walking around almost anywhere. I have traveled alone extensively in the U.S., Europe and Central America and have never felt so unsafe. About one block from the area (between the hotel and Union Square), there were very few tourists/business people. Instead of leaving my luggage at the hotel so I could walk around before my red-eye flight, I actually asked the people at another hotel (Grand Hyatt) to keep it for me because I was afraid to walk around by myself near the Whitcomb so late at night.If the area surrounding the hotel was the only issue I had, I would not be writing this review. While I wish the hotel's website stated clearly that it was located in an unsafe area, I do not feel that the hotel management can be blamed for what street people do around their hotel. What I do blame the hotel for is its terrible customer service. I was treated so unkindly by the front desk staff that I was upset all day and would never consider recommending this hotel or going back. This experience actually ruined a trip that I had enjoyed up until the last day. In all of my years traveling around the world, I have never been so unimpressed with a hotel staff's ability to show basic kindness, let alone good customer service, to its clients. Considering that I have stayed in 1 star hotels overseas and been perfectly happy, I am quite amazed that I had such a negative experience at a reputable hotel in a major U.S. city.

Oct 26 2008 	Not a great location	Hotel choices were limited in San Francisco due to a major convention and marathon. Hotel Whitcomb is located on Market Street. It is near a BART station, that was convient when taking the train from the airport. The hotel door was literally steps from the station.I really enjoyed my stay, but I wish the hotel had been closer to shopping and Fisherman's Wharf. The neighborhood that the hotel is in is not so great. I didn't feel very safe walking around, and took taxis home at night. Also in order to get to any areas by Fisherman's Wharf a cab is essential or if you plan on doing any shopping. There isn't a lot of places around the hotel for food or drinks, if you don't count the various Gentlemen's Clubs.Despite the less desirable location the rooms were clean, reasonable, and there was a Starbucks in the lobby. There also was a bar and grill in the hotel, but didn't have time to try it out.

Oct 26 2008 	A Grand piece of History	I only deduct one star because of the location. A beautiful grand hotel like no other. The staff wil treat you like you are at a FIVE star hotel. The rooms were clean and comfy. Yes, some renovating will need to be addressed, but you can overlook for the history of the hotel. We did leave early because of the location and moved to another hotel. The area has boarded up buildings, mens clubs and groups of young men and homeless roaming the street. It you don't go out after dark it is "probably " OK.The inside cafe was wonderful, and lovely to have a very busy Starbucks inside as well.It is an experience to stay here, and I was not unhappy when we left.Thank you Whitcomb staff for your super experience, front dest, hotel operator and conciere.

Oct 24 2008 	Nice Hotel Not So Nice Location	First and foremost, I rely heavily on tripadvisor reviews for all my trips. I take the time to read pages of reviews, dating back months or longer, then make a decision. I make it a habit of returing the favor and write reviews of places we stay. I have for years. The vast majority of reviews for this hotel are right on. But it is not the hotel, it is the area. And unfortuately for this hotel, the area comes with it.I visited San Francisco 5 years ago and lived in the outlying suburbs from 1981-1985. I booked this hotel due to the fact that my older daughter was staying here with a group of runners, participating in the Nike Womans Marathon. The bottom line is, the hotel is a great, older boutique style hotel with character and flavor. Our room was small, but typical of older, city hotels. Just like New York. It accomodated myself, my wife and my 15 year old daughter just fine. In fact, the hotel is not the problem. The problem is what is outside the front door and anyone booking this hotel should be aware of the area that it is in. It is on the edge of the Tenderloin district. It is no secret that this area of Market Street and the Civic Center is a haven for the homeless, those with apparent mental illness (albeit functional) and a large amount of the city's dregs of society. This is NOT a tourist area. I certainly understand this is not the hotel's fault, but if this website is to provide information to prospective guests, then those guests should be well informed. After arriving and checking in, we decided to walk to the Powell Street Cable Car turnaround. This is 4 blocks from the hotel. These are the cable cars that take you to Fisherman's Wharf and Aquatic Park, by Ghiradelli Square. Walking to Union Square would have been another 2 blocks longer. It was about dusk, maybe 630pm. I am a 20 yr veteran police officer in New Jersey, an hour south of New York City. I am not easily intimidated, but can sense when things are not right and am ALWAYS protective of myself and my family. Our walk lasted 2 maybe 3 blocks. I was so uncomfortable walking with my wife and teenage daughter, that we turned around and hurried back to the hotel. Flagging down a cab was useless. There were so many creepy, sketchy people hanging out, panhandling and eyeballing us. People getting high, dealing drugs and drinking out of brown bags. One guy asked me what time it was, and I could only infer that he got a glimpse of a fairly expensive watch I was wearing with a short sleeve t shirt. 20 yards later, I put the watch in my pocket and told my wife to do the same with hers. The hotel even gives its guests safety guidelines geared to the area it is in, in the hotel information book in the rooms. We stood out like sore thumbs. We got back to the hotel and told the desk we were uncomfortable walking to the cable car stop and could they call us a cab. The desk simply said to step outside and hail one. (Thanks for the help). Well, I tried that, and again was approached by several homeless asking for money as well as car service drivers hawking people for rides. Not pleasant. With that, I reluctantly got my car out of the valet service and we drove to Fisherman's Wharf and a few other spots around the city. This is not what I wanted to do. The next morning we checked out. Our stay was supposed to be for 4 nights. One was enough. And again, the hotel is fine, but why stay somewhere on vacation and feel intimidated and apprehensive when you walk out the front door.I am sure the hotel management will respond and state the city of San Francisco is aware of the homeless, the panhandling and the drug addicts and sketchy alcoholics and seedy characters that congregate and linger on Market Street in the area of the Civic Center, which is directly across the street from this hotel, and they are actively trying to do something about it. But the fact is, this is San Francisco, and it is a liberal city that is much more tolerant of this type of problem than other major cities, and it is not going away anytime soon. That is unfortunate for this hotel and I cannot possibly recommend staying here, especially with young children. As I stated previously, my older daughter also stayed in the Hotel Whitcomb with a group of runners in town for the Nike Woman's Marathon. She works in Manhattan and walks 10 blocks every day from the Port Authority on 42nd Street. Even she said this area is way worse then what she sees on a daily basis in NYC. She stayed with us in another hotel the last 2 nights. This review is an honest insight about a nice hotel that is in a not so nice area of San Francisco.
