Apr 18 2006	Not recommended for families but doable in a pinch	Our family of four (two kids aged 5 and 7) booked in here last weekend primarily because it was an easy option for us to take the BART straight from the SFO airport to the hotel. (It was $20 roughly, assuming you can work out how to use the BART ticket machines! vs $40 in a cab.) We were only staying two nights in SF before moving on, so a premium hotel wasn't needed.LOCATIONI read the reviews about the not so choice location, but our kids are used to interacting with homeless people in Toronto, so we took the chance. Be prepared though, if you are not from the USA, the amount of homelessness, substance abuse and poverty you see in this city may shock you. It is of a magnitude several orders greater than other big cities like Toronto, London, Rome, or Paris.Having said that, we felt safe enough in the daytime and there are surprisingly two very nice playgrounds nearby at the City Hall. We had no incidents, but it's not an area for a night time stroll with the kids of course. TRANSPORT In addition to the BART station it is easy to hop streetcars and buses East and West. The Civic area is not perfect for tourists, but we did a leisurely walk with the kids down Market Street to the streetcar turnaround, up to Chinatown (for lunch) down to the waterfront and back up Market street within about three hours with a lot of nice breaks along the way.The hotel has parking out back for $25 a day, or you can park across the street for $20 a day.EATING OUTWorth noting for parents, there are no family friendly restaurants within safe walking distance of the hotel in the evenings. You will need to order room service, get take-out or eat at the rather average restaurant in the hotel if you have kids. Or take a taxi/streetcar further down Market.ASK FOR A GOOD ROOM!We were a little unlucky with rooms at first (so it is worth asking for an alternative if you don't like what you are offered first). The first room we were offered was on the third floor. Although ours was a non smoking room, there are smoking rooms on this floor and it stank like an underground bar. The room was small, with a tiny window facing a wall. When we asked for an alternative we ended on the seventh floor in a nice clean, renovated room with a corner window facing downtown, for the same price.All in all, a place that is perhaps fine if you are travelling solo, or in a pinch, but ultimately not recommended for a family trip to SF.

Apr 17 2006	Clean Convenient 	My son and I stayed the week and found the Ramada Inn to be just fine. We had activities planned for every day, so the hotel was not the focus of our stay, just a place to bathe and sleep. I have read some of the complaints about the $25 a night parking and the general condition of the community around the hotel. Neither warrants any criticism. The gated, guarded, parking lot is just behind the hotel and only a few steps to the "back door". I saw no sign of any dangerous street activity, other than one or two homeless and panhandlers, similar to what you might find anywhere in San Francisco... or any other city for that matter. They leave you alone. Worst case, they may ask you for a quarter and "no" is an acceptable answer. Don't get all in a twist about it and enjoy a great hotel.

Mar 19 2006	A decent hotel in a Great location	I don't understand all the complaints about the neighborhood. Yes, there are some homeless people on market street, but they really never bother you. There are some porn shops up the street, but real travelers have seen porn shops all over the world. nothing too shocking there. the best thing about this hotel is its convenient location. my wife and is visited SF for a week without a car and hardly needed to take taxis at all because this hotel is SO close to public transit. We especially liked taking the "F" streetcar line that takes you all the way up to fisherman's wharf and north beach. the bus lines also take you straight to the haight neighborhood and the BART train right outside takes you all over the area, inlcuding straight to the airport. the room was tidy and well-maintained. and the hallways had lots of wood and mirrors, very classy. we also liked the 24-hr. starbucks in the lobby. definitely a good hotel for people looking to get out into the city and explore.

Mar 4 2006	Still a good budget option	I stayed here in March of 2004 (my review on tripadvisor is dated March 24, 2004), and on my trip last year stayed at the Westin St. Francis. I got my hotels at Priceline all times, the Westin for $73/night and the Ramada (both times) for $45/night. If you're traveling on a strict budget, the Ramada is not a bad choice. Wireless net access is now included, like a previous reviewer I found it dodgy (the signal would get lost) but I did not have a problem with spyware. I used the fitness center in the hotel room on this stay - it is a small room on the mezzanine with two treadmills, a recumbent cycle and a regular one and a stair climber as well as a not very good Universal machine. It isn't great but fine for a weekend stay. Hotel staff, especially the front desk, is very friendly and helpful. Oddly enough I was given the same room as last stay (perhaps because I only need a single bed instead of two). I like the decor, which is period to the hotel's construction (I'm sure it's been refurbished and is in decent condition); the bathroom though is very basic and the towels are thin and skimpy.There is still a problem with vagrancy around the Civic Center area, but I didn't feel unsafe. To look on the bright side, the hotel is incredibly convenient to Civic Center including the Opera House and Symphony, the Performing Arts Museum and the Asian Art Museum. Walk one block from the hotel up to Larkin and then cross Market and pass the Civic Center a few blocks to Eddy Street and you are at Saigon Sandwich, which has sinfully good Banh Mi. That area (the Tenderloin, now being called "Little Saigon") is filled with good Asian food.Looking at pictures of the St. Francis and recalling that trip, I felt much more pampered for about $40 per day more, including the fees for dial up access and the health club. If I had the money to spare, I'd spring for it. But I got everything I need at a cost of $54/day at the Ramada including all taxes and fees. I'll stay here again.

Feb 23 2006	Great staff!	For the price, I must say the hotel was great. I just had a few minor complaints but feel that they were handled wonderfully. Staff was very professional and friendly. after requesting a non-smoking room, at arrival I was told all they had available was smoking. No big deal, I know they are only requests. So the front desk staff promised to have a smoke free room the next day. After a busy day in the city we arrived back at the hotel to switch rooms. Not exactly what you want to do after a long day, but necessary. The room that they moved us to had not been cleaned properly. Someone's left over lunch was on the desk! I called the front desk and explained... we were immediately moved to a much nicer room! Freshly remodeled, biger bathroom, wonderful beds!! Great view!! what most impressed me was the hotel manager. I forgot her name... but after a little confusion about a rental car(long story) she drove me in her personal car to the rental car company!! She knew I was a little frustrated with the situation and she stepped up and offered to take me herself a couple of blocks down the road! In her own vehicle!! I would return to this hotel. The homeless people outside were not pushy or rude at all. And the BART station is literally right outside the front door.

Jan 17 2006	Depends what you are looking for	If you are looking for luxury or comfort, I would suggest another location. If you are looking for a place to rest your head and arent fussy, this place will do.Neighborhood: Many homeless folks and junkies. You must pass by porn shops and head shops before getting to union square. Quite convenient to shopping and cable car, BART. Probably not a great location for kids.Lobby: Nice, clean, presentable, helpful staffCheck-in: easyRoom: Very, Very small. Sheets on the bed were ripped/stained. WiFi connection was very slow and not encrypted. Bathroom barely built for one. The shower was a very small stall with no light so when you closed the curtain it was very dark inside. The sink was stained yellow and the towels were a grayish color and about as thick as a paper towel.Restaurant: Nice atmosphere and clean. Eggs tasted like old grease. Not sure how often they clean their grill. The man sitting next to me pulled a 10 inch piece of hair out of his breakfast. Overpriced for the quality you get. Staff is very friendly. Thankfully for there is a starbucks across the lobby.

Jan 16 2006	Decent price but will stay elsewhere next time	Just got back from a 4-day trip up to the Bay Area with my wife and we had decided to stay at this hotel based upon the recommendation of her father-in-law.My wife being from SF was able to point out certain benefits of staying here in regards to the location of different places that we were planning on visiting while out there. And for being a last minute trip, didn't have a lot of money to spend on something like the St. Francis or Fairmont. So I booked our hotel for 12 - 15 January 2006.Got to the hotel around 10:30pm and were checked in fairly quickly. And the up to our room we went and ended up realizing that we were pretty much staying in our own bedroom based upon the size of everything, including the bathroom and closet. Could have saved myself the $310 and stayed home. ^_~One of the key features that drew me to this hotel as opposed to some similarly priced hotels was their boasting of in-room wireless internet access. So out came my laptop and wireless card to check it out. Got into their wireless network only to discover that is was a)unsecure and b)not broadband. Speeds were like dial-up on a 56k modem. Dreadfully slow for someone who is used to DSL and faster speeds. But the fact that is was unsecure really frightened me. No WEP key needed. Just point, click, and connect. Needless to say I was in for a surprise the next morning when I found spyware had somehow found it's way onto my laptop's desktop. Two hours later it was clean again, but I had to plug my wireless card back in again for some info. And sure enough, within about ten minutes I had the same stuff showing up on my desktop again. Was not too happy at that point.For those bringing a laptop, be sure to not have any sensitive documents on there with you as you never know exactly how unsecure that network is. Or else keep them on a cd outside of your computer.Back to the room though. While small it was cozy. And for the first couple of nights we slept fine. But our final night we were there we discovered exactly how thin the walls were. The room next to our had been drinking (I had seen and heard them down in the lounge off the lobby earlier that night while I was getting a nightcap myself) and apparently had decided to continue their conversation up in their room... very loudly. I think I got two or three hours of sleep that night. The worst of the whole thing was at 6:30am when they decided to turn on the television and continue their conversation over the tv. Wife was none too happy about it.In regards to the rest of the hotel, not too bad. We enjoyed the lounge/restaurant off the lobby. I would go down there in the evening after our day on the town and had breakfast there on our second day there.We didn't have any issues with the homeless on the street... they weren't really prevelant at night, just during the day over by the Muni/BART station stairs. Only realy gripe I had was that if I were there with my family/kids I would not be walking up towards Union Square with them and passing some the gentlemen clubs that were nearby.Everything else though was okay from what we could tell. Would recommend being careful with electronics in the rooms though. The outlets did not seem to be too secure as some of my plugs would fall out easily when just brushed up against.In the end, not bad, but not great. Will definitely be looking for something a bit more upscale next time I visit the area.

Jan 13 2006	location location location	great central location but big homeless problem outside,,just ignore the bums and junkies and they dont bother you, some even offer unsolicited advice like ''smile dude your in san francisco''which i admit did raise a smile!!this hotel aint bad but its just not great either.olga the receptionist was very friendly.we had a multitude of problems with our room including the air con not working, the toilet cistern leaking, no plug for the sink or bath and the shower rail fell down.the place was clean enough though and the bedding changed each day it seemed.they need to sort out the hall ways on the floors though as they are very glommy and need some lighter decor.the starbucks downstairs was very handy!!my problem was the price of parking...$25 a day plus tax...$87 for three days parking to guests is a bit steep in my opinion.parking may be at a premium but as they have it why charge guests?good location, ok hotel, lousey parking charges!!!

Dec 31 2005	resuscitated hotel with exemplary service	No complaints here. Room was clean, bed was comfortable, maids were very nice & helpful as were all the employees. I did have to put a towel to the light to see if it had worn spots as some have said. They did, pretty funny but nothing to ruin my stay.Very accomodating service, we were gladly checked in early morning with no fuss, as our plane had arrived early. Street denizens? Enjoy the show! They're harmless & entertaining, besides, they're everywhere, not just around Market St.Location was fine, steps away from Muni & Bart, ready to whisk you away in seconds to your preferred destination.Take the ferry to Sausalito for a fun & cheap afternoon.Breakfast at "Steve's Cafe", directly across the street. Classic greasy spoon, good, cheap food, fun waitresses. The obvious #1 choice of the SF Police, I noticed.Seafood? Don't miss the "Anchor Oyster Bar" on Castro, a small converted coffee shop ambience serving delicious seafood. You won't be able to stop eating, a bit expensive & worth every bite!Unimpressed with food & service at "Sam's Grill" in the Financial District.Very impressed with the "Cheesecake Factory" at the top of Macy's at Union Square. Great food, great view, great price, great service & long wait for a table. Now I know why.

Nov 20 2005	No complaints this end!	Me and my father stayed here for 7 nights 2nd to 8th Oct 05 and we liked the hotel very much.Ok, it's not The Hilton but the room was tidy, everything was in working order and the maid service was fine in respect to cleaning, bedsheets and towels.I imagine it's been a while since a lick of paint but we didn't feel the hotel was shabby or run down in anyway.The location is excellent for BART (literally outside the front door) and only a few blocks away from the busy shopping area (Virgin, Apple, Sony Metreon and Union Square).You could throw a stone at the City Hall, Library and Civic Centre (including The Bill Graham Auditorium).I couldn't say enough good things about the lobby/reception staff though, they are real people people and an excellent source for local information. They clearly know and love their city very much.I am very surprised by the negative feedback on this hotel from other users of this site. There is a strong presence of homeless people in the city and especially on Market Street. If you are scared of homeless people don't stay on Market Street as you will feel very uncomfortable. Myself and my father are from Bristol in the UK and we are very outgoing in our own city and county so we are used to this sight and don't have a problem with it.The homeless here do ask for change but they do not act threatening.If we return to San Fran, I imagine we will book here again.

Nov 16 2005 	Yikes	Interesting old building. Rooms are large but tired, grubby, and dirty. The most frightening feature is the neighbourhood: a vast number of homeless people on Market Street. I really wasn't comfortably going to or from the hotel. I did not enjoy my stay in the hotel or the city as a result

Oct 29 2005 	Oh dear....	Cheap indeed, but a sketchy location. The hotel is a great old building with an elegant lobby, but the rooms could use some serious maintenance. I was moved from my first room due to a plumbing problem. The second room had a broken door lock, pitted bathroom sink, and broken television. And what a lumpy mattress.Cheap, convenient, and practical for those doing business at the civic center, but not a great way to spend a holiday.

Oct 11 2005	Hotel is A-OK	I was astounded to read the negative reviews of this hotel. My husband and I (both in our 60s) spent nine nights here, returning from SF Oct 6, were very pleased with our accommodation and would return. Our room on the fifth floor was on the back of the hotel and very quiet. It was medium-sized with one queen-sized bed; the 3-piece bathroom was small, but did have room for two. Everything had been refurbished and was spotless. All the appliances were in good working order -- lights, phone, tv, shower, toilet. Staff were very helpful and pleasant. The food, service and prices in both the Starbucks located right in the hotel and the hotel restaurant on the ground floor were first-rate. The hotel also has an Internet cafe and a small gift shop. We used the BART station right outside the front door and MUNI running down Market Street. (We didn't have a car, so no experience with hotel parking.) The only possible drawback was that the area between 5th and 8th on Market (the hotel is on the corner of 8th) is derelict and grubby, but always crowded when we were on the street between 8 am and 8 pm. No one approached us, although some passersby did look somewhat unsavoury.

Oct 11 2005	Family stay at this hotel	We spent our first trip to San Francisco this last week end. We flew in on Friday night and took the Bart to the hotel. A friend of ours said this was the best way to get to hotel and it stops right out front. We got off at the correct stop but came up to the street from the wrong exit. This was 9:00 PM at night and we were traveling with our 11 year old son. Our son was a bit scared by the homeless people on the street and then we went the wrong way down Market street. We aksed at a movie theater and they were very helpful and we were only 1 block from the hotel. There were lots of people on the street so I did not feel worried but if you are not used to seeing homeless people it will scare you. The hotel is very ornate and the staff were very nice. The bathrooms are small in the rooms but our room had been recently upgraded and was nice. The staff were excellent and gave us good advise on how to get to the different attractions etc. The orpheium theater is accross the street and the UN plaza was accross the street and on Sunday they have a farmers market in the plaza which seemed good and was attracting large crowds. If we go back to San Francisco we will book a better hotel in a better nieghbourhood but if we needed to we would stay in this hotel again.

Sep 27 2005	Watch Out for Ramada	Hotel is literally terrible. A British Hotel would not get away with the service. Towels were like rags,in fact they were rags. Decor was depressing and noise dreadful. Worst of all was the location. SF has become world capital for vagrants but this area of Market St seems to be populated entirely by vagrants.The authorities in SF will need to address the vagrant problem or the tourists will get the message that they do not care. Vagrants approach you everywhere in the city and while they are not aggressive it remains a problem. In general it will be some time before I return to SF.

Aug 20 2005	Nice hotel but...	We enjoyed our stay at the beautiful historic Ramada Plaza Hotel. The rooms were elegant and spacious with wonderful high ceilings. It was clean and very nicely decorated. The staff was friendly (except for 1 day shift bellboy) and helpful. The restaurant/bar was a wonderful place to hang out in and through the huge windows watch the SF city life. Plus having Starbucks on site was great too. But...as nice as the hotel was, I probably will not stay there again. The location is good and bad. Good because it is halfway between the Union Square/Moscone Center/Financial District and the Civic Center/Opera district. The gorgeous SF city library and city hall dome was right outside my room view. It is bad because it is also at the border of the Tenderloin district. The security within the hotel was excellent, but as a woman traveling with two kids, I did not feel comfortable walking to or from the hotel as soon as the sun started going down. I had to rely on catching cabs if I was out after dark. During the day it was not a problem since there were so many other people besides the homeless and drug addicts walking around. Plus as soon as you walked away from the hotel the stench of urine was sometimes overwhelming. I know that the street people are some of the many things that give SF its colorful character, but this was a bit much.

Jul 29 2005	Close to pubic transport book there if you can get it cheap	I stayed here for a couple nights in March through priceline. I had read plenty of reviews and I am familiar with the layout of the city. Personally, I don't mind staying in this type of area to save a little cash. I never spend much time in the hotel room other than to sleep, so for $54 tax included- I'll take it. The ease of public transport from here was what sold me on this hotel.This is a 2 1/2 star hotel, so you can't expect the Ritz Carlton or you will be very disappointed. You can get to the BART and MUNI in less than 5 minutes from this hotel and then go wherever you want. The room was okay, a little outdated, small bathroom, and no fridge. I did have an iron which is nice and the walls don't seem too thin. In fact there was a prom party there when I was there and people were partying across the hall, but I was still able to sleep. I walked around the street alone past 12:00 at night and never had a problem. No one ever said anything to me. Yes, the sights aren't too pretty especially on the streets behind the hotel. Yes, there are homeless people laying on the streets at day and night. But, I never heard any gunshots, shouting, fighting, etc. I would recomend staying here if you are not with your family. Probably not the best scene for younger kids. Probably not the best scene if you are trying to impress your girlfriend, boyfriend, or significant other. But, if you are trying to save a few bucks and you want a good location give it a shot.

Jul 10 2005	Terrifying and Awful!	This hotel and its neighborhood redefines scary urban blight. When we arrived from the airport, several bell hops and staff of the hotel rushed out with dollies to take our luggage. At first, we thought this was indicative of the fine service, but actually they just want to rush you off the street before you're eaten alive by drunken bums. We stayed here for one night (we were supposed to stay for four) and couldn't sleep the whole night. There was constant screaming from the homeless fighting in the street, gunshots, etc. We kept the TV on the whole night just to block out the noise. The hallways and the room were dark, dank, and past their prime. The bathroom was small, old and musty. I wouldn't have taken a shower there under any circumstance. The first and only night, we tried to venture out to see the city, but we were accosted by violent lunatics within ten seconds. The neighborhood is so seedy that the banks lock up the ATM machines at night (I've never seen this before).YUCK! I would never even think about staying at this hotel again.

Jun 22 2005	Better than expected	Both the hotel and the neighborhood have seen better days. putting that aside the rooms are on the small side but almost have the character of a bed and breakfast. Housekeeping was first rate. Bart will take you from SFO to 200 yds. of the hotel. Streetcar stops at the front door. The f line is fun and you should get a passport to use it on all forms of transport-a real saving. The best part-- stayed for $61 & tax from 6/15 to 6/21 through Priceline. After a great deal of research I found that this is a rate that can't be beat at decent SF hotel. The homeless and the wackos are around-just avoid eye contact and keep walking.

Jun 21 2005	Pretty good stay	I stayed 4 nights at the Ramada in May. The only thing that I didn't care for was the small room and bath. Would go for a larger room next time. The room was very clean though.There were some homeless in the area outside the hotel but they were not that aggressive. The hotel was very convenient to public transportation.I would stay there again.

Apr 29 2005	Bad neighbourhood	I stayed at this hotel for four nights in late April 2004. The lobby of the Ramada is quite cool (it used to be the old City Hall), but the rooms are fairly run down and not particularly clean. All in all, it wouldn't be too bad for the price, but the neighbourhood was not very safe or pleasant. There are not too many businesses in the area (most of the places are shut down permanently) and it is a haven for homeless people. As a single woman, I felt very unsafe in this area after dark and didn't particularly enjoy walking around in the daytime either, because I was asked every 10 feet for money.

Apr 21 2005	It was great. I don't know what everyone else is talking about.	I visited the Ramada last week and spent one night there. I wish I had booked it for the entire week I was in town. It's in a great location. Everything is in walking distance. The Muni is right in front there's plenty of restaurants. Powell street is about 5 blocks down. Okay, so there are a bunch of homeless people and all but so what you're in downtown San Francisco. If you want to avoid seeing this than I suggest you stay away from any major U.S. city or keep yourself locked away in a resort somewhere. My room wasn't huge and neither was the bathroom. But I paid $89 for one night. The hotel has a beautiful lobby and the decor is nice. I mean if you're going to Frisco to visit the hotels than maybe consider the Intercontinental or some other 5 star. The staff was great even when I checked in at 1:30am and they allowed me to have a late check out. There's a starbucks right next door that you can access from inside the lobby. Parking is a problem everywhere in San Francisco but I parked across the street for 18usd a night which is pretty decent considering it's right on Market street. This hotel exceeded my expectations. I would stay again.

Apr 8 2005	Wow! Scary location needs work!	We went with some friends. We have been to San Francisco many times since we live only 3 hours away. It has gotten so bad downtown that this is NOT a safe place to stay if you are planning on leaving the hotel. I won't get into it, but we were actually fearful of our safety do to the # of crazys hanging out in front of the hotel. As for the room, our air conditioner cover fell off twice in the middle of the night making a huge thud! scared the B-Jesus out of us. We had to park across the street in a dicey lot since hotel parking was full...That was really bad...25.00 a day to get accosted as you try to get to your car. As for the bathroom, it was so small, and I am not kidding, that you had to use a shoe horn to get in and out. We laughed off the whole trip (since we weren't mugged) and just won't stay there again.

Mar 27 2005	economic and clean	I didn't have high expectations at $90 a night. The lobby is ok with the marble floors and chandeliers but the hallways are long and dark maroon. The room was small but clean. The important thing was the convienience. From the Starbucks downstairs, to the multiple lines of transportation in front of your door. The F line takes you straight to the Wharf and Pier 39. Its not glamourous, its convienient. If you are the type to spend the entire day site seeing, then you should consider the Ramada. If you like to lounge around in your room, this isn't the place for you. The bell hop suggested not to go to the area where the San Franscisco Mission is because of the Mexican element. What was in fact disturbing was that upon visiting the Mission I saw that the surrounding area was very well maintained by white families, and gays. Thank goodness I didn't listen to the bell hop. I would've missed beautiful historical site. CHECK IT OUT!

Mar 24 2005	not as fancy as we thought...	I stayed there during August 2004, the neighbourhood was ackward, a lot of homeless people right in front of the hotel... The room we had was very small, a horrible bathroom, we couldnt even move in the shower, and the room was not that clean !the staff was friendly, but we were surprised by the excessive price of the hotel parking ! Thought it wasnt worth the price we payed for.Would not go there again, and certainly not in that nieghbourhood !

Mar 17 2005	Nice Hotel Convenient Location	I stayed one night at the Ramada Plaza Hotel on 3/8/05. I was worried about the quality of the hotel given the reviews I read, but was immediately reassured the second I saw the hotel. Compared to other places in downtown S.F., it was clean, safe, and welcoming. The lobby appeared to be quite classy and done up. It was pricey, but not uncommon for downtown. I thought it was worth it for the quality. I paid about $130 including tax and parking. (It could possibly have been a bit more!) There's a reservationist available 24-hours a day and the staff all seem extremely friendly. I had to ask the night front desk person for a toothbrush and he kindly had TWO sent up to our room along w/toothpaste. I didn't even have to ask! Parking is always an issue when staying in the city. I paid $25 for one night. The good thing is it's in a gated lot and there's an attendent who monitors incoming traffic. I felt safe having my car parked there. I chose this hotel because of the location and because it's a 3-star hotel. It's about 1/2 mile away from the Warfield theater, which is where we were going to a show (GO GAVIN DeGRAW!) and about a 3/4-1 mile away from Union Square. The walk isn't bad (10-15 min.), even at night. There were homeless people around (inevitable in the city!), but Market St. is well lit and they don't bother you if you just walk on by. (It was just me and my 19-year cousin and she and I didn't have problems.) A cab ride cost about 5.00 (including tip) driving between 2-3 miles away from the hotel. Now, if you're hoping for a good night's sleep staying in this hotel, good luck. The noise should be expected if your room is facing Market St. There's nothing you can do about it. I probably got two whole hours of sleep! If you're worried about this, bring ear plugs or ask for a room facing away from Market St.The room itself was very spacious compared to other hotels I've stayed in in S.F. We got a non-smoking room w/two double beds. There was A/C and heat and the windows opened, which was nice during the day to get some "fresh" (Does that exist in CA?) air. The bathroom was clean and also spacious. I'm not sure about how the other amenties are. We mainly stayed here because we needed a place to shower and sleep between shopping and our show. Overall, it was a great experience and would not at all hesitate to book another stay here!

Mar 14 2005 	Outstanding value--dicey neighborhood	This hotel exceeded my expectations for a AAA 2-Diamond or Priceline 2 1/2* property. No, it's not a luxury property, nor does it bill itself as such. Also, the neighborhood is fairly dangerous, but not if you go right into the BART/MUNI station which is right in front of the front door. Nevertheless, it had every convenience I would expect in a 3-star hotel, such as a well-equiped and maintained exercise room, bell service, concierge service, room service (until 10 PM), and fast, modern elevators. The room I had, at least, was quite large for a big-city hotel, and I didn't hear my neighbors (or possibly I didn't have any). My only complaint was that the mattress was quite old and kind of saggy. The MUNI station at the front door will take you just about anywhere you want without having to transfer, including the financial district, Union Square, the Embarcadero, the Castro, fisherman's wharf, golden gate park, Pac Bell Park, and the zoo. I recommend this hotel highly for any budget traveler who can hop on a subway or trolley car and doesn't need to walk around the immediate neighborhood.

Feb 20 2005	Good Value/Great Staff/Dodgy Location	I have stayed at this property several times on business trips when I had a limited budget. Since I am working, I do not spend too much time in the room. Every visit, I have found the staff to be very friendly and helpful. If you take the right exit from BART, the Hotel entrance is just steps from the station exit. It is also a few blocks from Davies Hall, where the Symphony plays. The down side of the location is that this is not a great section of Market and most people probably will not feel too comfortable walking at night. So, take BART or the ample public transit. The hotel is nicely kept and clean. The building has some interesting architectural details. Still, it is an old and somewhat tired property and some of the remodeling is not the best. Same for the fitness center -- the room and equipment are older, but meet my needs. The food is good, but overpriced. If you are bothered by traffic notice, ask for a quiet room in back. The rooms in front overlook Market, which is a busy street. The staff, the price and the BART station make the difference for me.

Jan 12 2005	Great value Hotel	Having read some of the reviews here I was wondering if I should try to change reservation. However the hotel was fine. I found all the staff to be friendly and efficient. The room was clean and more than adequate. O.K., some of the furnishings or wall covering were dated, but it was not a problem. The lobby is really nice.There are lots of homeless between 5th and 8th street on market but we did not get any hassle on our 5 days there, and walked that patch (10 minute trip) by day and night. People will ask for money but not in a threatening way.All public transport is right on your doorstep. We bought a citypass which was great value and we never waited long for a bus or cable car or streetcar to arrive.We paid $60/night including fees on hotwire and for that money we housed two adults and two children in style...a bargain in my book.

Dec 2 2004	Ramada Plaza Civic Center A beautiful hotel	When priceline accepted my price and gave me Ramada Plaza Civic Center as my hotel, I was very happy. It's a nicely remodeled old beauty, right on Market at the Civic Center. It's a great bargain too and looks & feels more like a four star hotel though it's ranked only 2.5 stars. I recommend it!!!

Nov 29 2004	Excellent accomodations	Stayed for 3 days for our 13th anniversary. Nov 28 2004	Not a Big Fan	This was my first time staying in a San Francisco hotel and I was on a budget. Nov 18 2004	Does not deserve the bad press	I stayed here for four nights recently on a business trip. The hotel is old and the rooms are consistent with a hotel of this age. My only negative comment is that the bedspreads and blankets are old and need to be replaced. I was unable to confirm this, but I heard that they are remodeling the rooms one floor at a time and that the rooms on the 7th floor and above are complete. I stayed on the fourth floor. The bathrooms are small but clean. The room is reasonably well lit and has a window that you can open to let in fresh air. The food at the restaurant in the hotel is above average and much better than I expected. The New York strip I ordered was excellent and priced appropriatetly. The bartender at the lobby bar is very good. His service was way above average, he helped me get a shuttle from the hotel to the airport and even made sure my dinner arrived in plenty of time so I was not rushed. There is a significant amount of homeless people on market street, but once you get off of market the problem drops off signficantly. Nov 18 2004	I would stay again!	My girl friend and I stayed here to go to the Raider/Bronco's game and we enjoyed our stay. The hotel is old but has a lot of character. we did have to ask for a new bed spread but they were quick to bring a shrinkwrapped freshly laundered spread. The Starbucks in the lobby was great! and Burger king just across the street. The staff here was wonderful, very helpful. Parking is terrible though. Make sure you enter on market street from the east and park right in front while unloading baggage. Dont Panic, this may seem like you'll get a ticket or that you're in the way of traffic but this is accepted. there is NO parking at the hotel so park in the lot at the east corner 8th/market (just across the street to the east). It will cost you $18.00/night but it is secure. get the all inclusive transportation pass and use it instead of your vehicle. you'll see why when you get there! Its cheap and will get you on the cable cars, trolley cars busses and I think they call it the F line. Just a few blocks away is Buca Di Beppo (italian restraunt), you have to try it.

Nov 5 2004	Not my top pick in San Francisco	Hotel needed updating...furniture and carpeting was well worn. View from window looked directly into the rooms of the Holiday Inn next door. Oct 26 2004	10 times better than the reviews to date	Made reservations for the Civic Center Ramada through Yahoo travel/Travelocity. Stumbled across the reviews here and became nervous.Experieces was great. Old hotel but helpful staff, nice room. Well worth the money paid.

Oct 25 2004	Good to stay! Great Value	On a vacation at San Francisco, stayed at the Ramada Plaza with family of two other adults. Our package was room and taxes only through EXPEDIA, did not include breakfast. The hotel is very conveniently located at the CIVIC CENTER, a few yards to the MUNI and a block away from the SFO Information Center. The hotel is very clean but the bathrooms are small, not surprising considering the prime real estate it is located on. Do not expect the spacious rooms of a suburban hotel! The bath and toilets are very well maintained, the service is very efficient and the reception staff very friendly and caring. However I tried to reach the hotel from the airport at 1 p.m. to verify if we could check in earlier than the 3 p.m. scheduled time and strangely were asked to come in person to find out. We did however using the BART (another reason to stay at the RAMADA as the BART conveniently connects direct to the AIRPORT - a ride of 5$ per person with all baggage) and were graciously checked in at 2 p.m. A starbucks right on the property offers a T MOBILE HOT SPOT (pay for use - I chose the 10$ option for day long connection). The hotel does not provide Internet facility. All tour operators stop at the hotel to pick up guests, and tours can be booked from there. The N JUDAH MUNI takes you to the Golden Gate Park, the F MARKET takes you to the Fisherman's WHARF, the BART takes you to BERKELEY, all within a minute of walk from RAMADA. The Hotel also allowed us a late check out at 1 p.m. A good hotel to stay if you really do not mind the long and high corridors typical of older buildings; to reiterate though, we found the rooms are well lit, efficiently airconditioned and maintained immaculately.

Oct 14 2004 	great for the price!	I am writing in defense of this hotel. I have stayed at this property about 5 different times in the past two years. But all very nice. I found the bath rooms to be a little small... but again... I was only paying 60 a nite in a great location in SF. The parking price is a little steep... but you can find parking very close by for a lot cheaper. Yes... there are a lot of homeless people in the area.. but what large city does not... I never have had a problem with them. I know that if you get a discount price on this hotel you will be very pleased with your experince. When ever I am on a budget in SF... this is where I stay.

Oct 8 2004	Not as bad a people say its a san fran experience	Got this room from priceline for only $55 so perhaps my review is tainted by the fact that I didn't pay $150/night to stay here, my expectations were lower :) The hotel lobby is very nice, it's crowded and noisy, I love that. If you want silent then don't stay downtown. I feel the hotel captures the San Francisco experience perfectly. Here's why ... 1 - The rooms are small, old, and renovated. Bathroom was old looking, naroow and small. Everything was clean. But San Fran is small and cramped and old, as was the hotel. But nice ... 2 - The homeless love the area around that hotel, no complaints. They are absolutely harmless! Homeless are a part of San Fran no matter what. The steet where the hotel is was amusing, we couldn't help but laugh, interesting stores. Not the expensive and chic part of san fran but we spent no time in that area, just passing by mainly. 3 - The location was very nice, we walked everywhere. It was very close to everything4 - Parking is a problem, as is the case in the entire city. You can easily park around the hotel area for about $8/day which isa great rate since the hotel charges around 30 but you have to remove it by night. We parked in the financial district the entire time w/o paying a penny and then took cabs, limos, or even walked everywhere else.If you want a good feel of the city stay here, it's not disappointing. If you get a good deal it's worth it but when we checked it the rate was $160 and I would not pay that. But if you want to be in the fancy uptight area in a $250/night hotel so be it, you just get a different perspective of San Fran.

Sep 22 2004	Rooms small and noisy	My wife and I stayed 2 nights at the Ramada Plaza (9/17 - 9/19). The room was very small, and the noise off the street was bothersome. Parking per night was $20.00. Sep 15 2004	A Pleasant Surprise	I booked a room at the Ramada Plaza Downtown San Francisco several months ago for a five-night stay the week of Labor Day. After reading the many negative comments I was fully prepared to go to another hotel if I wasn't satisfied; I got a great rate of $55/night on Hotwire so it wouldn't have been a big financial loss if I left. However, I was pleasantly surprised and I would stay there again without hesitation.The hotel is conveniently located at the Civic Center BART stop--about a 30-minute ride from the airport for only $4.95. I arrived several hours before the 3:00 p.m. check-in time and the front desk clerk was professional and accommodating; I was given a room immediately.The room itself, though it might have been tight for two, was very comfortable for me alone. It was quite nicely furnished with pale yellow tone-on-tone striped wall paper and what appeared to be quite new carpeting and matching draperies and bedspread. There was a small walk-in closet with ironing board and iron. The bathroom could have used a bit of cosmetic upgrading--and the shower's water pressure could have been better--but it was otherwise clean and well-maintained.The lobby was really very nice and it was convenient having the Starbucks right there. There is also a restaurant just off the lobby which I tried one evening when I was too tired to go out. The food is just fair, and overpriced for the quality, so I'd skip it next time.Yes, there are homeless people outside the hotel but that's true of most of Market Street and Union Square as well. I wasn't harassed at any time and I also didn't witness other guests being bothered. They mostly seemed to be your basic burned-out, left-over San Francisco hippies.In addition to its proximity to the BART train, the hotel is convenient to the MUNI trains and busses. If you enjoy exploring a city on foot as I do, you'll find that the hotel's well located for walking to Union Square, the Casto, SoMa, and many other neighborhoods.Overall, my stay at the Ramada was a good experience at an exceptionally low price. I've certainly paid far more for hotels not as nice, including other more prestigious S.F. hotels that were disappointing.

We had a few drinks here on another occasion, and it seemed like the bar was well used by locals (especially for the sports on it's many TVs) which we took to be a good sign. We had breakfast across the road at the Hollywood Cafe, based on recommendations on this site and were not disappointed. Our 5th floor room was well appointed,clean and comfortable with a good supply of hanging and drawer space. We had ordered a fridge for the room (from a pre arrival email sent by Hyatt) which was on site on our arrival. We also made good use of the guest laundry (wash $1.50 dry $ 2.00). All in all for a three day visit we had no regrets about returning to this hotel.

Sep 29 2009 	Very Fancy Not The Best Value	This Hyatt is not well marked so if you dont look at pictures of the front beforehand you may have some difficulty finding it but once you do youre in for a treat. The staff is extraordinarily pleasant. We ended up upgrading our room to an Oversize King option so I cant speak for the regular rooms. The location is fantastic; youre within easy walking distance to Fishermans Wharf if you go down the hill and Ghirardelli Square if you go along the street. There are other sights you could try walking to but I wouldnt recommend it and the #47 bus goes right by the front and that will take you to most of the more distant places youd want to check out.Parking is insanely expensive but San Francisco is a unique case when it comes to parking, you can park for about $32 per day if youre willing to walk 2 blocks from a nearby parking garage at the Walgreens which is actually a significant savings over what the Hyatt wants to charge.They do love to charge you for everything. Internet either on TV or WiFi (but not both!) is an extra $10 per day. The TV Internet is dodgy, the wireless keyboard needs a perfect line of sight to work and even then you better hunt and peck because anything faster wont work. Frankly Id rather have something wired to the desk that works than a fancy wireless keyboard I could try to use in bed that doesnt. And the controls are far from intuitive, read the menus carefully before proceeding. Its a little outrageous when you think any Motel 6 charges $3 for WiFi per day and at a Travelodge its usually free but with the money youre paying to stay at a Hyatt its more expensive than most other places. I suppose their regular guests can afford it and the business people can write it off anyways. They have the $5 bottles of water but thats fine with the vending machines and Walgreens nearby and pretty standard. They do provide free whitening toothpaste though which I thought was a nice touch, and plenty of towels and pillows all around.The TV was nice and well placed. The room came with a coffee maker but the coffee it produced wasnt worth the time, two sips and the rest you want to send down the drain. The desk/TV stand was very handy and had electrical outlets coming out its ears in very convenient locations which we appreciated. The phone by the bed however had so much static on the line it was incredibly hard to hear who you were calling. The dcor was fantastic.The bathroom was very modern and stylish which was nice but the door wasnt really a door so much as a sliding wood panel as if you were stepping into a closet and it was a heavy wood with no proper handle so you really had to thrown your back into moving that thing and it didnt have a lock which wasnt a concern for us but may be for others. The bathroom was large; there was no bath in our room but rather a very modern-looking shower where water essentially cascades out of the ceiling. It sounds great but the pressure isnt the greatest and since you cant really adjust the head coverage is splotchy.Overall we were really impressed however the room did lack one thing  there was actually very little information about the hotel itself. It mentioned some services and numbers you could call which was grand but it didnt have, for example, the hours of the pool. Nor did it state if local calls were free, which they almost always are but after the price of their internet access I began to wonder. It had a room service menu and some limited information about their restaurant but after 11pm it all pretty much shuts down. What good is room service that stops before midnight? Usually room service is a godsend when you get back late at 3am or something and want a good meal.On the whole this is an excellent location if you can afford it but dont expect the greatest value and while they do the grand flourishes and stylistic touches fantastically they seem to sometimes lose sight of the practical.

Sep 29 2009 	Location is great clean but I think you could get better value..	The Hyatt Fishermans wharf, is clean and in a great location. The nightly rates are most likely similiar to other hotels in this popular area. The pool area is clean, but nothing fancy. Just a pool (heated to 80, which is not really warm enough considering it does not get a lot of sun and it's located outside but with 4 hotel walls around and only the sky above to see the outside world. This hotels charges 10 a day for you to hook up your lap top in your room and 6 .95 for 15 minutes of use in the hotel lobby computers. This to me is a bit of a cash grab. Breakfast as with other Hyatts is not free, there is a neat popular place (hollywood cafe) accross the street. However if you stay in the Holiday Inn express (accross the street) you will get a free hot breakfast. The sports lounge in the Hyatt (Knuckles) has good food, friendly staff and many TV's to watch available sports. The Hyatt does have a great gym, better then most and with great equipment.

Sep 26 2009 	Great Location Good Room Odd Hotel Layout Terrible Restaurant	The hotel is two blocks from Fishermans Wharf and around the corner from the Powell-Mason cable car terminus. The F-Line trolley is a block and a half away, next to the all-night Walgreens. Its an easy walk to where the ferry to Alcatraz leaves. You cant beat the location if you want that classic SF tourist experience. The room was large enough and well-appointed. The staff was very pleasant, although a woman at the front desk subbing for the concierge sent us to a restaurant (The Slanted Door) without reservations but is so popular George Clooney probably couldnt have gotten in. Instead we had to walk down the wharf looking for Plan B, which was very nice (The Waterfront Restaurant). The layout of the hotels upper floors is very odd. People actually got lost getting back to their rooms. To get to our room from the elevator required 140 steps and four turns. Skip the restaurant. We had our first breakfast there. The breakfast buffet is truly mediocre, the kind you usually get for free and console yourself that at least it didnt cost you anything. But here it costs $18 each plus tax and tip. There are a couple of interesting breakfast places across the street and a Starbucks around the corner. We had a drink in the restaurant/bar in the afternoon and it was full of screaming football fans.

Sep 25 2009 	Excellent location!	My spouse and I stayed at Hyatt Fisherman's Wharf for 2 nights in May 2009. The service was great, the room was super clean and amazing. Great view of the Coit tower from our room. There's nothing like a super comfy king size bed after a long flight! We got a travel agent deal, so we were very pleased with the price, but we've also seen very good deals online/via Trip Advisor. Breakfast was not included, but there were so many cafes and restaurants nearby. We prefer to eat a a cafe for breakfast anyway. The pool was amazing, lots of sunshine during the day. Close to lots of attractions as well as trams and buses. Alot is within walking distance. The hotel had everything a 4 star hotel should have. We highly recommend this hotel! Wireless internet is available at a cost. I think this is SF's newest Hyatt hotel. It's a modern building, with a beautiful brick fasade in the traditional wharf style. The hotel has 313 newly renovated deluxe guest rooms, incl 8 suites and Hyatt business plan accomodations. Loved it!

Sep 23 2009 	Great location - decent hotel.	We liked the location and the beds are excellent. Hollywood Cafe across the road is great for breakfasts. Knuckles in the hotel makes great burgers. Stayed at many nicer places for a lot less money.

Sep 23 2009 	Good location newly refurbished rooms and good base to explore San Fran	Located in Fisherman's Wharf it is an ideal place to explore San Francisco. The location is pretty similar to that of the Sheraton, Holiday Inn and Hilton- all of which are nearby. It is only a couple of minutes walk to the Wharf and Pier 39 and other attractions.We just wanted a hotel that was well located and clean and this excelled these requirements. The room was spacious, clean and bright and the bathroom wasnew and of a very high standard.Whilst It was nothing out of the ordinary, it was of a high quality.We booked through Priceline and the hotel was significantly cheaper then prices quoted on standard travel websites so do look around.

Sep 22 2009 	Was pleasantly surprised by Hyatt at Fisherman's Wharf	I was really impressed at how modern and elegant our room was. The location can't be beat. We relied on the consierge Victoria quite a bit and she provided excellent recommendations. I think the best thing about the Hyatt though was that they were able to accommodate a late check-out for 3:00 PM which really helped us out quite a bit. For a hotel in the center of a touristy area around the middle of the price point, it was much nicer than I expected.

Sep 17 2009 	GReat Hotel BUT Stung with the Parking Cost!!	were in the City for 2 nights $114 for parking!!! rip off its cheaper in london, hotel is very nice and great location. room eate was great but the extras i.e. wifi, bottled water, parking and such is a rip off!

Sep 15 2009 	lovely hotel	We were in San Francisco for 2 days during a longer trip to Las Vegas. The hotel was lovely, room spacious with good facilities. The location was good for the cable cars and fishermans wharf. Enjoyed every minute of our stay in San Francisco!

Sep 14 2009 	Quality hotel top service and ideal location	What a great place to stay! Had 4 fantastic nights here in a room with two doubles with a package including buffet breakfast. The room decor isn't exactly bright and colourful but it was so comfortable, exuded quality and was amazingly quiet - we had plenty of room for family of 4 even with all our suitcases. All facilities in the room were top rate even down to the iPod clock radio.Front desk, valet and bell desk staff all outstanding - extremely helpful and friendly. Service does make a difference and virtually without exception everyone went out of the way to ensure we were having a great time. The guy on concierge needs to lighten up a bit however. The pool and spa are only about 3' deep and small but fine to cool off in if it's warm!Knuckles restaurant is great - in an evening go for a selection of starters with some draft beer, you won't need a main course. Selection for buffet breakfast was maybe a bit limited but of high quality. There's a Safeway 2 blocks away.If the cable car stop is busy (always late afternoon/early evening) take a cab for around $10 to Macy's and catch the cable car back to the hotel. Fisherman's wharf is okay but very busy, dirty and grubby - go once but DO NOT bother with Boudin's, it's just a rip-off and the food was rubbish. Rent a bike from behind the hotel to bike the Golden Gate Bridge and include the Sausalito ferry route. It's a very easy ride (walk up the few short hills if need to) and you can take as long as you like.Parking is expensive but we only picked up the car on the last day before heading off but it was worth it.

Sep 12 2009 	It's alright but we wouldn't return	Stayed here for 3 nights as part of a 2-week trip to SF. This hotel has some very good aspects: it's close to the pier, so there's no hills to climb. However, it's a bit too far to walk to Union Square. (We stayed on California St for the rest of our trip, which was walkable for both F.Wharf and U.Square.)The staff was very professional. Breakfast in Knuckles (which is nice room, with a trendy-ish bar; there's also cool wooden beams on the ceiling) is table-service or buffet at 18dollars for fairly good food. The front desk and concierge area is nicely decorated. The pool is fine and the area gets plenty of sun, but the pool water dried out our skin more than usual! (not sure what's going on with that.) The fitness centre is very good: treadmills, bikes and cross-trainers (all with TVs); weights, drinking water, sanitising wipes, cold towels, dry towels, earphones.The layout of the hotel is extremely confusing: you'll find yourself getting lost along the maze of green (read: 'puke-green' walls and brown carpets) hallways to find your room. In fact, the decor on all floors (except the lobby) is absolutely depressing (seriously!!) and there's no natural, and very dull artificial, light in the hallways. The decor in the rooms is not much better - they're a sad grey, with brown carpet. Let's just say, you won't look forward to coming home to your room.Toilet and shower, but no bath; the toilet doors are a bit weird and don't fully close; there's also no fan, so you may need to de-fog the mirror with your hair dryer. You'll also hear everything in the toilet from the room! Nice flatscreen TV, 2 phones and a safe. Comfy bed. If you've your laptop, internet access is 9.99 for 24 hours of a pretty speedy wireless connection through a T-Mobile hotspot (so you could use an existing T-mobile account on your credit card, or charge it to your room). There's 2 PCs in the lobby but web access is something like 6 dollars for 15 mins!!! However, they do offer free access to the websites of all airlines leaving SFO, so that you can check-in online and print your boarding pass. It's also possible (but difficult) to print documents for free from your memory stick (but you need to be a bit wiley, and I think I wasnt supposed to be able to do it....)Vending machines, and a washing machine & dryer, on each floor; however, the venders were a bit fussy, some were out of order and you'll need dollar bills (they wont accept higher denoms).Overall, its not a terrible place but management needs to work on cheering up the accommodation. They've tried to be trendy- and some of it works - but I would really sack whomever did the hallways and the rooms! We certainly wouldn't return, as there's plenty of better, less weird, more cheery places in the same price range.

Sep 7 2009 	Great place for 50 and over!!	Great location and great staff. The hills of San Francisco can be hard for this age group. The Hyatt is located at Fisherman's Wharf and within a easy walk to the Pier. The Hollywood Cafe is across the street. They serve a wonderful hugh breakfast for around $8.00. Wonderful staff and customer friendly. Sight seeing tours can be purchased at the corner. We highly recommend the hotel!

Sep 1 2009 	Good hotel for the money	We had a very good stay at the Hyatt at Fisherman's Wharf. So many things we liked have already been said in other reviews. The staff is super nice. Everyone smiles and is very helpful which is nice when you're on vacation. The room was very nice and clean. Our ipod radio didn't work when we first got there but a staff member was upstairs and had it fixed in minutes after we called. The hotel is very central to lots of the action on Fisherman's Wharf. Every night we walked down to the beach and out on the pier to enjoy the view, the sunset and the people watching. One cable car turnaround is right behind the hotel and the other one is just down a couple blocks. There are lots of good restaurants nearby and it's an easy walk to Pier 39, which is crowded and crazy but fun. Also nearby are Ghirardelli Square, the hop on, hop off bus tours (highly recommended), bay boat and Alcatraz tours, the aquarium, sea lions, and lots of other fun things to see and do.I first arrived at the hotel for a conference and my husband joined me later and we made it a long vacation weekend after the conference was over. The conference facilities and services such as food were very good and as far as I know the people who planned it were very pleased with the hotel.Two very minor complaints...We felt the breakfast buffet at $18 a piece was pretty pricey considering it was basic breakfast foods like scrambled eggs and bacon with nothing really fancy or unusual. But it was very good and it is, after all, Fisherman's Wharf and food there is expensive.Also, we wish we had had two chairs in our room so we could relax and look out the window, even though it was to the front of the hotel and not much of a view. But it's fun to people watch. We never pursued it but my guess is that if we had, the very nice hotel staff would have found us another chair.We'd go here again. Good value and nice room.

Aug 30 2009 	Great place to stay	I stayed at the Hyatt from Aug 22nd thru Aug 28th with my husband and two children 14 and 12. We arrived around 1pm and room was not yet ready but they took our bags for us and we went to get lunch and when we returned the room was ready. We were pleased with the room but when the bell boy brought our bags my husband mentioned that we would have liked a better view but it was OK (Our view was of a courtyard) The bell boy told us the hotel was full but if we were staying for a few days then we may be able to move the next day, we said we were intereseted and he said he would try to make it happen. The next morning I went to the front desk and the women was very pleasant and helpful she brought up our account and said they would be able to move us that day, she told me just to pack up and leave the bags in the room and they would move us while we were out for the day. And they did just that when we returned around 4pm our bags were in our new room on the 5th floor over looking the trolley turnaround on Taylor and Bay ave. Also when I reserved the hotel I requested a refrigerator which was not in our room when we arrived but when I called the desk to ask about it they said they would send one right up and it was there within 10 minutes. There is a safeway (supermarket) two blocks away, go out of the hotel and turn right go straight for a block and a half and there will be a parking garage on your right and the entrance to the supermarket is inside that garage, we made many trips here since our first breakfast at Denny's cost us over $50 we decided we would try to cut back with breakfast and some lunches and eat dinner out, and if you take a minute to fill out the paperwork for a safeway card you can save alot more. One day we bought rolls and lunchmeat for sandwiches but I forgot about plastic wrap and/or foil so I went downstairs in the morning and asked a woman that was putting away the complimentary coffee if there was anything I could use for this and she was helpful enough to go into the kitchen and get me some foil. Everytime I asked anyone for anything they were more than willing to assist me. I would definately recommend this hotel, the alarm clocks are I-homes and my son had no problem charging his I-touch on it. Besides the high price for parking that everyone has mentioned, which did not bother us since we just got a 7 day muni pass and rented a car when we needed it, which was only to go out of the city. The only complaint I could possibly agree with is the internet fee $10 per day seems high,I was under the impression that you could log onto their computers for 15 minutes at a time for free but that is not the case those 15 min will cost you $6.95. I'm just glad I did all my research ahead of time and we didn't really need the net, we were on vacation after all. you are able to sign on and check bags and print boarding passes for free which was nice. The muni pass is great the trolleys are normally $5 one way although they are busy on the weekends during the week we used them frequently. The F-line is also cool to ride but we also used the buses alot they can get you anywhere in the city you want to go. If you plan to visit Coit tower there is a bus that takes you up to it, this is one bus worth taking we did not know about it until we got to the top of the many, many stairs that you must climb to get up there, definately take the bus and then for a small fee ride the elevator to the top of the tower for some great views all around the city. Hope these tips help you out.

Aug 22 2009 	Favourite hotel in Fishermans Wharf yet!	Stayed at the Radisson in 2002, the Holiday Inn in 2004, so thought I would try the Hyatt this time. Good choice and the most upmarket yet. Clean & modern room, very quiet and comfortable. Staff very friendly and got a good rate through cancelling and rebooking when the credit crunch really hit in January / February and the prices lowered. Would stay here again - an easy walk to the Whard and Pier 39.

Aug 22 2009 	Great location for activities at the wharf and cable cars	We stayed at this Hyatt over July 4 weekend and couldn't have chosen a better location. Close proximity to the wharf, ferries, cable cars and trolleys. We planned to go to Alcatraz, Suasolito and a Giants game just to name a few activities and all were easily accessble from this location. One caution that has nothing to do with the hotel. We got the Muni Passes thinking that we could easily hop on a cable car or trolley from anywhere. Over a busy summer holiday weekend catching cable cars took a long time. If you are rushed to see the sites you may want to opt for one of the on/off tours readily available.At the hotel we were pleased with the pool - even though it was small, this isn't a resort and I'm sure the weather isn't usually so accomodating to sun bathing. The fitness room was AWESOME. We worked out every morning - it did get a little crowded at times but still, it was a holiday weekend and I'm sure they were totally booked. The equipment was new and fairly plentiful. They could have used a little more room for you to use the weights. There were plenty of weights but not quite room for two people to use them at the same time.Rooms were fine - clean and quite. The floors are numbered oddly so it is a little confusing. Knuckles the restaurant was great for breakfast but the Hollywood Diner across the street also does a great breakfast.

Aug 21 2009 	Great Location	My husband and I truly enjoyed our stay at this Hyatt. Its location is very convenient to Fishermans Wharf. It seems like the other reviewers have it right. The parking is VERY pricey (but we didn't have a car, so it did not apply to us). A few additional notes:- On their website they recommend Airport Express as the best way to get there... We want to warn you that this is a CRAZY ride. It is comparable to a roller coaster through the city. It was easy to use and inexpensive, but be prepared for an uncomfortable and sometimes scary experience.- The pool is located on the third floor which we found strange. Just a heads up if that is where your room is located. It closes at 9 PM (probably to accommodate those sleeping on the third floor.) There were lots of people using the pool and hot tub during our stay and they were both not large enough to accommodate everyone.- The bathroom does not have a locking door. (Hopefully you are quite comfortable with the person you are staying with.) There is no exhaust fan for privacy or drying out the room either. The shower "door" is a glass panel that only covers half of the shower so the spray goes all over the bathroom. Make sure you have plenty of towels down. It looked like the hotel was going for something ultra modern, but failed to think the space through all the way.- Knuckles is the restaurant attached and has great food. We ate there twice.- The internet is not free. However, you can use it at no cost to print your boarding pass.

Aug 20 2009 	No complaints at all	Booked at the very last minute and got a room. When I checked in they were very apologetic that they were overbooked because of Alcatraz Triatholon. So they put me in the other (better) Hyatt for one night and then upgraded my room.Had a great 2 room suite, free bottle of wine, free internet - in fact they couldn't do enough for me.I would definitely stay here again. Great location, good price and friendly helpful staff.

Aug 11 2009 	Eat at the Restaurant Don't Stay at the Hotel.	I made a reservation with this hotel, on their company website in early July for a weekend stay in early August. I got an email asking me to check in online, which I did...I show up to the hotel at 2:15. My room wasn't ready-- okay fair enough, their advertised policy is 3pm checkin. I sat and waited an hour (they said they'd call my cell-- which never happened). I check the front desk at 3:30-- my room still isn't available. Mind you, there are tons of people getting checked in in the meantime, getting their keys and going up to their rooms. The front desk people were polite, but for some reason they seemed not interested in having me as a customer. They offered no helpful information other than to tell me my room wasn't ready with no estimated time for checking in. No worries-- I won't be back.The room was clean, but rather drab for the price. The bed was very, very comfortable. The shower was nice and roomy, with good water pressure.This property is clearly coasting on its location, however-- a shame, since I've stayed at the Marriott, Holiday Inn and Hilton (not at Fisherman's Wharf, though) and gotten way better service. Go to one of these (especially the Marriott, which I've never had a bad experience with) before looking at the Hyatt. Save yourself the potential aggravation.I ordered room service, which was excellent-- all the food I ate was fantastic -- do visit Hyatt's restaurant, Knuckles, if you are on the Wharf...it is a cheerful, friendly place with great food!

Aug 10 2009 	Decent.	Hubby and I spent 3 nights here in August. All in all, the hotel is a solid 4 star experience. Great location, decent amenities and friendly staff - exactly what you would expect from a Hyatt, with no surprises. We checked in late (around 9pm) and were given a room with a view of the building's AC unit which was a disappointment as I had booked a room with a "city view" through Hyatt's 1-800 number. Front desk explained that they cannot guarantee a city view. Why offer it at the time of booking,then? At any rate, the next day we were switched to a top floor, corner suite with a great view of the city.Room service is good and Knuckles (lounge) is very average. The bathrooms in both rooms were updated but very dark and unwelcoming. A decent place to stay, but nothing "special" - if that's what you are after.

Aug 8 2009 	A good deal - no bad surprise	I recently spent one transit night, after a good deal cought [--]The hotel is 2 blocks from Fishermans'Wharf, i.e, a lot of restaurants and attractions are at a walking distance.Our corner room was quite impressive and very comfortable (the bed was +++).Finally, nothing to die for, but an excellent and reliable place.

Aug 3 2009 	Great location and staff	This hotel has a great location, just a few short blocks from Fisherman's Wharf and within walking distance to Ghirardelli Square, Pier 41 (if you need to catch a ferry), and SF's North Beach neighborhood which has some good restaurants. We were initially booked in a corner room on the fifth floor, but the street noise and a bed with a deformed mattress made a room change necessary. The front desk was extremely helpful (as were all staff) and apologized for the inconvenience and moved us to a quieter room with a better bed. The iPod-compatible stereos are a nice touch and the bar/restaurant looked very nice, though we did not eat in it.

Aug 2 2009 	Good Location Good Price.	Great location to Pier, within walking distance to Trolly, pharmacy, shopping outside pier. Booked for $82 a night on Priceline. Room did not have view, but we didn't care. I am a Gold Member but I did not receive a newspaper each morning like I was supposed to. I would book again.

Jul 30 2009 	Great place/location for families!	The Hyatt at Fisherman's Wharf is the most ideal hotel for families, whether it's young kids or teenagers. With an outdoor pool, great proximity to Fisherman's Wharf attractions, Pier 39, the cable cars and North Beach...everything worth exploring is within a short walk. Additionally, even though my children are a little older (14 and 16), they so enjoyed the hotel's passports, with stamps to illustrate our journey through San Francisco.
Jul 30 2009 	Great hotel and location!	Perfect location on Fishermans wharf. Very nice rooms and bathroom. Flatscreen TV. We had a view of the city and we would definitely stay here again! :)

Jul 14 2009 	Excellent Location	Very nice hotel -- clean, great location, very comfortable. Laundry facilities available -- which was a nice perk. High rates for internet service. The main reason we chose it was for it's location -- which was perfect. Walking distance to fisherman's wharf and pier 39. Close to an IHOP for breakfast. Parking was quite expensive -- $45 per night; but they were very pleasant and quick.

Jul 10 2009 	Exceeded Expectations!!	Wonderful Experience. The staff was phenomenal and were very concerned with ALL of their guests. WE were given a great rate on parking and the breakfast buffet. The hotel staff even let us keep our SUV in the garage on out last day because we could only book the last Alcatraz shuttle...no extra charge even though we had checked out.THe room was in great shape and the cleaning staff was very quiet and respectful.

Jul 2 2009 	What a great value!	We searched on-line for a hotel for our 'trip of a lifetime' with our girls and found Trip Advisor to be very helpful. It's through this site that we determined the Hyatt at the Wharf was our target: We were happily surprised!I booked with the Hyatt reservations phone number & got all we wanted: away from elevator & ice machine, with nice view and quiet: 5th floor facing Coit Tower. We pre-paid and got a good deal for a 7-day stay (thought not as good as a PriceLine-type deal).We were only in the room at night for sleep, but the location was great, hotel clean and staff pleasant & friendly. We ate at the restaurant & found the food very good, but not too cheap.Only negative: housekeeping never got it that 4 people in room meant we needed 4 washcloths & 4 towels. But a houseman quickly brought needed cloths/towels each night & front desk sent fruit tray to make up for it.Found Airport Express to work well, too, pre-paying at $14/person round trip. Enterprise car rental 1 block away; Budget close, too.In all, the Hyatt made our 'trip of a lifetime' just that!

Jun 29 2009 	Great Stay at the Hyatt	2 Weeks at the Hyatt from the 8th to the 22 June 2009, as per previous advice we didnot partake in the breakfast and went to the Hollywood Cafe across the street, which was amazing both in the quality of food and the value. the hyatt itself was an excellent hotel, we booked it via hotwire at $89 per night. For this the value of the hotel was excellent, I requested and got 2 double beds and a fridge for medication that I carry, this was all sorted out before we arrived for which i was most grateful. The staff were excllent friendly and helpful, especially Luz on the front desk. The room was spacious, the beds supremely comfortable, we had no problem with the width of the walls as some previous travellers have indicated, this may just be floor specific, we were on the 5th floor. In all I would reccomend this hotel, this is the 3rd time we have been to San Francisco, the 2nd on fishermans wharf, In all it was the best stay we have had.
